Abbott—Messrs. Abbott had nothing to do with it except give the certificate; they were chartered accountants; Mr. Weller did the work—I under
stood that the liquidator got a fresh set of books; I did not see them—Messrs. Abbott and Co. gave the certificate in December, 1894, but we never saw the fresh set of books—they would be written up then at Messrs. Abbott's offices; they never came to the bank—it was that question of writing up the books that led to a considerable delay in the preparation of Messrs. Abbott's accounts—they were there three or four months, and I at times, under the direction of the board, was pressing Abbott's to hurry up—the only question that arose between the books that were kept under the suggestion of Mr. Weller and the books that were ultimately written up by Messrs. Abbott was as to the system—there was no question that I had not included everything—when Mr. Weller came in to make the audit, the books had been used before; they contained entries of everything that had gone on before then; but they objected to the system—the share warrants were made out to bearer, but only for the founders' shares—Mr. Brandreth did not suggest that the shares should be made out as share warrants—I think a form was printed—the shares in England would be registered shares, but all the founders' shares were share warrants—the principal distinction between the share warrants and the ordinary certificates for registration is that the share warrants pass by delivery to bearer—I do not require a register of shares with share warrants—the bearer is the holder—I have here the account of the establishment expenses—they begin to be entered on April 18th, 1893—that entry was made in pursuance of a minute on April 18th passed by all the directors, and according to that entry we start by this, that the amount due to A. F. Baker on promotion account is £6,909—on April 11th the matter was referred to a committee of Mr. Lambert and Mr. Stokes to consider the expenses which were brought in by Mr. A. F. Baker, as having been incurred as establishment charges and report upon them, and then apparently they sit as a committee and consider this matter, and on April 18th the matter is brought before the board, and there is the minute: "Having been submitted to Mr. Stokes and Mr. Lambert these gentlemen reported that they had been through the same and were satisfied with the amounts and that the same were in order, showing that the sum of £6,909 had been paid by the fouuders, thus leaving a balance now due to them of £4777. It was agreed that the agreement dated March 10th, 1892, so far as cash payments are concerned, should be reduced, and in lieu of the amount therein men
tioned the aforesaid sum should be accepted," that is, £6,909—on March 20th a banking account had been opened at the London and Midland Bank of the London and Scottish Bank by a payment on credit of £3,700 odd from Mr. A. F. Baker's account to the London and Scottish account with the Midland; that was taken over—the exact amount was £3,400, I think—that was the difficulty between the auditors and myself when they

came in—on April 8th certain amounts had been received and paid into A. F. Buker's accounts, and they were received by the founders and promoters, and had not gone into the London and Scottish Banks account; and those amounts had to be accounted for therefore—the copy of the account spoken of in the minute as presented by Mr. Lambert and Mr. Stokes to the board I never saw; we simply had to go by the amount—it was agreed that the establishment charges were to be £6,909—as against that there were payments that had been made by Mr. A. F. Baker either for the account of the London and Scottish or to the account of the London and Scottish Bank, for which Mr. Baker was entitled to be credited in the accounts between them—that was the question that arose with Messrs. Abbott and the liquidator—this account contains the ex
penses made made out by me from the minutes—it was agreed in the fninutes that the sum to be still paid to the promoters was £2,477, not because the agreement of March 10th was to be altered, but because they had had that amount already; that was the position—my explanation is this: the sum of £4,777 was paid by the directors after the company went to allotment; then sums had been paid before that—Messrs Abbott make it out that some £8,000 was spent in establishment and promotion expenses; that is in the balance-sheet—this £4,777 represents a sum that was actually paid after the company went to allotment, by the promoters—the sum of £3,000 was paid before that—I made in the ledger these entries from the minutes—I must have had some instructions, because it says here, "Less deduction from agreement, dated March 10th, 1892"—I never saw that agreement—I opened this account soon after April 18th, and then I entered those other payments as they were made, but that agree
ment of March 10th, 1892, never reached me; I never saw it—what I entered in the book is what I thought it was, from the minutes, certainly—it was agreed iu the minutes that that sum of £4,777 was still to be paid; then the auditors, when they came to examine the account, found that instead of taking £3,477 over from A. F. Baker they should have had over £6,000—they found that he had received the application money and certain sums paid into the bank on allotment—that is the only explana
tion I have to give—I can explain that entry—Birtwhistle had sent £200 to Mr. Beall, or somebody connected with Mr. Beall, in 1892, and he wanted ordinary shares—it appeared that the matter was quite forgotten, and after the company went to allotment Mr. Birtwhistle wrote and asked whether he had been allotted his ordinary shares—then this amount was traced, so that it had to be accounted lor—it was pait of the money of the company; that was the view I took of it—I debited them with that £200, under instructions, so Mr. Beall said at once, "Oh! this matter has been overlooked"—the £4,777 which was still to be paid is made out paid by the two credits of transfers from Beall's account Nos. 1 and 2, and the sums granted by the board periodically—the cheques paid out by the board were always in pursuance of resolutions—Mr. Beall never overdrew more than was due to the promoters—in order to get all the accounts square he had been paying himself in that way, and then the accounts were transferred so as to finish the. whole thing up, the £4,777—the amount which had been actually overdrawn by Beall on Beall's account No. 2 was £1,215, but in order to square up the whole of this account they debit him with the exact balance, which happens to be £4 10s. more

and the result of that is that the whole account is wiped off and then the promoters have been properly paid the £4,777, which was still due—the £3,477 was the payment over by Baker—the next sum, £526, was a shareholder's cheque payable on allotment—they are receipts from no one else but shareholders—the next is £917 10s.; that is a number of cheques than had reached the bank and were placed in one payment in that fashion—they were a portion of the allotment; they were maue payable to Baker—Messrs. Abbott, I may mention, always complained that the establishment expenses account had nothing to do with the promotion account—I have got the establishment expenses account before me—the cheques as granted by the board are in consecutive order, but other entries, such as the balancing entries, are simply the totals; they could not be in this ledger—the last three entries were made when the amounts were found to total to £4,777—I see Beall and Co. No. 2 account closed in July, 1894—as soon as the entry was found to total the entry would he made—it may have been a month or so afterwards, but there were no further payments made—in the account of Beall and Co. No. 1 the latest entry may he August 15th, 1893; in No. 2 account a transfer is made in December, 1894—that is the balancing entry—I have only got the totals here; I cannot speak as to details—those figures were arrived at by current account over the counter paid away by Mr. Colee, the cashier—Mr. Beall was provided with London and Scottish cheque-books, and he drew the money over the counter, so that those figures were taken from the current account, and had nothing to do with the directors at all—in May, 1893, the debenture prospectus was about to be issued—from March 17th or 20th until May 25th, 1893, the bank was discounting bills and doing the best business it could with the money it had—at that time there was not much money to work with—if with a small capital they could earn a fair amount in discounts and commission, the more money they had to use the better—on May 25th, 1893, Mr. Stokes, Mr. Lambert, Mr. Greville, Mr. Carruthers Wain, and Mr. Brandon, the solicitor, attended the meeting (The minute was here read)—the debentures were to be the security of whatever the bank had—from time to time the debentures were to have the security of a floating charge—the agreement was signed for the offices in George Street, Edinburgh, which had been taken on agreement in May, 1893, at a rental of £80, and on that day the insurance for the guarantee of the staff in the office was increased from £1,200 to £2,000, £500 apiece for four of us (Further extracts from the minutes were here read)—no business resulted from any
thing the French committee put before the board, and in the result Mr. Brandreth was discharged—a dispute arose with regard to the furniture at the office in Paris—an action was brought by certain people, on behalf of the debenture-holders of the European Contract Corporation, in which they claimed that the furniture on the premises at the offices of the London and Scottish Bank belonged to the debenture holders, and thereupon the London and Scottish Bank intervened in the action, to protect the furni
ture, their own property—Mr. Brandreth obtained about that time, or some little while afterwards, a judgment against the London and Scottish Bank, ejecting them from the premises—that judgment the London and Scottish Bank asserted was fraudulently obtained by Mr. Brandreth—I think that was the tone of the proceedings—in my affidavits I stated that

Mr. Brandreth had fraudulently obtained this judgment behind our backs, in order to get the benefit for himself and to oust us, and thereupon the action proceeded, the London and Scottish Bank claiming to have the offices and the furniture—we had paid for the lease at that time—they were desirous of going on with their business there with somebody other than Mr. Brandreth—as a matter of fact, the directors and Mr. Brandon went across, to take forcible possession of the premises, so as to oust Mr. Brandreth from the fraudulent possession which they said he had taken; and they got possession—it is the fact that from June, 1893, until the end of September, 1893, the company continued doing the same business, the discount business and banking business that they had, to the best ad
vantage, according to their capital—in October, 1893, or the end of Sep
tember, this question arose with regard to the preparation of a statement, 80 as to show what the position was for the six months—I was instructed to make a rough balance-sheet, a rough draft, to show what profits had been made for the six months—I proceeded to do that, without the assis
tance of the board in any way, but by the assistance of the staff; and the board interfered in no way whatever with that until the thing was com
pleted—there was not a great deal to do; I think I did it all myself—none of them had it until it was ready for the use of the board; there had not been a great deal of business done up to that time, and it was a simple matter to do it—all I had to do was to find out what had been the outgoings and the incomings, the receipts and the expenditure—the first item was to ascertain how much had been received by way of discount and commission—there was no other source of revenue at that time—there were shares which they had received, and that was taken into account after I had presented the statement—suppose there had been shares which could have been sold in the market at a profit of £1 apiece, they would have to come into account in ascertaining what the profits were, and against that I should have, to take into account what had been the working expenses of the company, salaries and rent and other payments, directors' fees—I cannot remember the figures; it is quite im
possible, I have had no access to the books for five years—a detailed statement of what had been received in that way was annexed to the statement I have drawn up; it was added to it—I cannot remember what the totals were; I presented a statement to the board and gave all the details—one of the items of which I gave details was this amount of commission and discount—I cannot tell you the balance within £1 or £100 at this date—it would not take long to find out from the ledger—it was well on for £1,000, I believe, the amount that had been received—it was not a balance at all; it was simply a statement of either side—no balance was struck—it showed a statement of receipts and expenditure; that is all—the question of pro£t was not taken into account at all, be
cause the payments were spread over a certain period of time; for instance, a payment was made of £64 for electric lighting—I could not take the whole of that into account for the first six months—the board dissected the accounts afterwards—in the account which I prepared I did not put on one side all the items that had been paid out, regardless of whether they were for the six months or twelve months, or longer: but the current slips prepared for each of these entries would show everything—it would not be so much as £ 100,

but if there was an account of £100 for stationery, and I had £70 or £80 worth in stock at October, 1893, I should only take into account what had been used, and then again stamps had been paid for by the board for cheque books and other things, and the stamps were still there—when I prepared the minute I knew very well what the statement was for—it was in order to see whether the profits had been sufficient to enable them to declare an interim dividend—I am not clear that the statement as prepared by me was in the hands of the board, and considered by them for some time—I remember Mr. Wain and I and Mr. Beall going through the account afterwards—you may call it a committee from the board—it was not considered by the full board—the committee of the board met, I suppose, before we came to a final settlement of the account—I was brought into the board-room, and certain suggestions were made, and they were carried out—the official half-year ended on September 13th, so that I had from then to October 3rd to prepare this account and adjust it—I was instructed to take certain items out, and to spread them over—that is to say, items such as those I have given you—it was considered unfair to charge the first half-year's working with these items—the decision they arrived at was that the whole of the preliminary expenses could not possibly be debited against the trading for six months—right through to the end you will find "the secretary presented a statement"; that is simply a minute in the book; he did not do so; I simply handed it in; I was not there when it was presented—"The secretary presented a statement for the financial half-year ending September 13th, showing gross profits £2,785 48. 1d., and net profits £1,269 13s. 4d."—I wrote that minute from the agenda, of course; not that day, the minutes were always written a week afterwards, not on the day, but at the time I entered this up I had no reason to doubt that it was right—the figures were arrived at after the board had dissected the accounts—I never presented any such account with those figures—there is no account made up after the figures were dissected by the board—the figures wore "added and the additions were made afterwards, and it was left in the board-room—I did not make the additions—I did not make the alterations—the statement was simply altered and retained by the board—it was in the possession of the board, I know—I saw it afterwards, certainly, but only the totals from the agenda paper, which was always signed by the chairman, and from that I entered up the minute—if the chairman was not there on the day, the chairman who officiated for the day would sign it—it never came back into the outer office—I did not make the altera
tions—I made the minute from what I found on the agenda—in February of 1895 I was examined before Lord Stormonth Darling in Scotland in the liquidation proceedings of the London and Scottish Bank (Exhibit 258, read)—I was being asked about the statement which I had referred to as having been presented according to this minute, showing aprofit of £1,269 13s. 4d.; it is the same statement in an altered form—my answer then was: "It was in the hands of the board; it was presented duly to the board"—I say so still, undoubtedly, but in an altered form; it was not altered outside at all; it was altered in the board-room—the minutes were altogether wrong when they say thai the secretary signed it—I say I presented a statement; it was altered by the directors at the board room, and I never saw it—

I cannot see that there is much in not saying that when I was being examined in Edinburgh; but it never came out of the board-room—I said, "So far as I know, it is in the hands of the liquidator; it was amongst the other documents "; so far as I know, it is still—I said that it was pre
pared by ray instructions; I believe I did it myself; I may have had some assistance from the other members of the staff, but, speaking at the pre
sent date, there was not much of it, and I do not see why I cannot have done it all myself in one day—I was asked about a number of questions—I know I presented a statement to the board; it was altered in the board-room, and never came out—I did not give that answer then; the question was not pressed in Scotland in the way you are doing it now—I am practically of the same mind that I was then; I say it may be in the bands of the liquidator now; it never was in my possession—it is misleading to say that the secretary presented it; that is right through the minutes from beginning to end, and it is mis
leading—I wrote it all from the agenda paper; it was always done in that fashion—I did not present it personally—my explanation is that the statement was handed into the board-room; it never came out after; it was altered there—it was never presented by roe or any of the rest of the staff after it was altered—I said, "None of the directors took active part in making up the account"; I say so still—it is only that one account that is dealt with; then I said: "It was submitted to the board (Q.) Prepared by you and submitted to the board?—Prepared by me and the staff. (Q.) Did the four directors, before they authorised the payment of this 7 per cent, dividend, take any means to satisfy them
selves that the profit had really been earned?"—they may have done so—the chairman, before the dividend was paid, may have had the statement in his hands for a week; I do not remember it now—I have already told you to-day that it was a committee of the board which passed the account finally—it was not on the same day—whether before they authorised the payment of a 7 per cent, dividend they took means to satisfy themselves that the profit shown on that statement bad actually been earned is not within my province—the directors had the opportunity to satisfying them
selves that the statement prepared by me was correct; they had the slips of paper which contained the details of each entry along with the statement—Mr. Beall was questioning me; he insisted on being in Court—the statement, as prepared by me, contained the then value of the securities the bank held, and their various assets; the value of the deposits that we had negotiated, and the sum that had accrued to the bank; we held it as security, undoubtedly; if we discounted a man's security that was our security—the statement contained the then value of the securities which the bank held; in this statement that I prepared, for instance, you will find that Colonel Schaffer had a discount of £782; that was down in the statement, and what had accrued to the bank in discount for the same—the man's bill would be the only security we had—I was asked, "Can you say from your own knowledge, as an ac
countant and secretary of this company, that the directors were entitled to declare a dividends and I said, "Yes, it neemed all right;" it was a qualified reply—it goes on, "The sum to be expended on dividends is not

a large one"; that is a qualitiod reply—they passed it, I did not pass it; I had nothing to do with it except to fill in the minutes from the agenda paper afterwards; so far as I was concerned, it ended there—I took no responsibility at all—it was put to me, "It was not bonus, but it was earned?" and I replied, "Yes, according to the statements submitted to them, and they satisfied themselves about it"; that is altogether mis
leading—I did not submit any statement that warranted a dividend being paid; I could not have said so in evidence—I remember the cir
cumstances perfectly well; there was a strong discussion between the chairman, Mr. Beall, and I as to whether the directors' fees should be taken into account—they were taken into account on the statement I made; that was a most important item; it was the largest item in the account—it was taken into account in that statement—I cannot remember what the directors cut out—I did not say just this minute that they cut it out; I said there was a discussion on that point; it was talked over in the board-room between the chairman, Mr. Beall, and myself; that was the largest item to come against the profits; it amounted to £21 per week, about £480; it was the largest item I know of in the account as I drew it; against the net profit—there was a strong discussion on that point, but I know the ac
counts were cut up in such a way, they never reached me afterwards—whether I have ever made the statement in any affidavit or in any ex
amination that you make to-day and that you made at the Mansion House, is impossible to remember—I know tliere were a great many affidavits being made—from beginning to end there was litigation right and left while the bank was running—I cannot remember having talked over this matter at all with anyone—I have got a fair grip of the matter yet—I do not think I said anything in 1895 that I could not practically verify to-day—an interim dividend of 7 per cent, was declared, which took some £400 odd—if the net profit was £1,269 138. 4d., which paid away £470 odd in dividends, supposing they had made that profit, or anything like that, they had done wonderfully well with the little capital they had had; they had a small amount then; therefore, the more capital they did get the better thoy would be able to do, if they could get it on moderate terms—so far as that prospectus for further capital was con
cerned, that was a further issue of 50,000 ordinary shares; at a little premium if I recollect right—what had happened with regard to the ordinary shares was that none had been issued at all until March, 1893, when the first issue of 100,000 shares was made—then in October they did as they had power under the articles to do; they issued a further 60,000—I cannot say whether the two Sheridans were clients introduced by Brandon and Nicholson, the solicitors to the bank—it may have been so, but I do not remember at this dare—Brandon and Nicholson acted as solicitors to the Scottish Bank until April, 1894, I should say, roughly speaking—they acted for about 12 months; that would cover the time—it was during that time that the Sheridans were introduced—Brandon and Nicholson were also solicitors for the Sheridans in certain proceed
ings; I am not sure whether they were solicitors for them all through—I think Mr. Greville, a friend of Mr. Brandon's, acted for Mrs. Sala—he was a solicitor, and was also a director of the Scottish Bank—the Theatrical Trust was either Mr. Greville's or Mr. Brandon's business—I believe they

also acted for the British Refuse Company; Greville was the solicitor to that—Mr. Beall may have been averse to the trafisactions being entered into with the Sheridans—there may have been conversation on the board, but we did not know anything about that; we cannot say one way or the other—I cannot remember at this date if the bank was advised by Brandon to advance this money to the Sheridans—it may have been the case—that is six years ago, and I am not clear upon that point—wheu because they took away certain documents—I know we claimed certain documents from them—there was litigation—I cannot remember at this date if I swore this: "In the month of August, 1893, under the advice of Jocelyn Brandon, of the firm of Brandon and Nicholson," etc. (Beading to the words). "and that the security was a valuable one"—if the affidavit is there, of course, it had been made—I was in the habit of making a lot of these affidavits at that time—they were all prepared for me—it is within my knowledge that Messrs. Brandon and Nicholson haveactedfor the Sheridans recenily, and it is possible that they did at that time—if Bran
don advised that this would be a valuable security, that was done by the board; that wasnot within my knowledge—the London Refuse Company's shares were, in the view of myself and the staff, at that time a very valuable security; we looked upon them as being very promising indeed right up to the finish; up to the end; I think, really, Mr. Beall did—when I went to Scotland he told me that a lot of these shares were going to be knocked into cash immediately, and I quite believed him—I thought they were very valu
able, and so did he—in pursance of what I heard in regard to it I sent out the circular which states, "We have had offered to us the opportunity of con
tributing to a limited syndicate, the object of which is to form a company to acquire and work Livet's patents for London and 20 miles round"—it says, "My directors, however, have made inquiries as to the value of the patents, and also personally had an opportunity of inspecting the. in
stallation at Halifax, and of seeing the results, and are so satisfied with the great value of the invention, and the bonafides of the undertaking, that they individually have joined the syndicate to form the London com
pany"—the particulars which were sent with it were to show what Livet's patent was to do—I remember there was an enclosure went with that cir
cular—when the accountants came on the scene, that is Abbot's, we were urging them to complete their accounts; chey were there for three or four months—the directors told me to hurry them up, and I did try to hurry them up to get the accounts finished; they were a nuisance in the place—the first conversation with regard to what I was to do when I was going up to Scotland probably took place a day or two before December 6th; I know I left on the 6th—it took place in the board-room of the bank, I presume—we had only two directors at that time—I do not think they were both present; it must have been Mr. Beall, the chairman, I think, I am not clear on that point—I know Mr. Beall was there, and one of our directors—it is within my knowledge that Mr. Wain was there the night I left for Scotland; he came there that afternoon; that came to my knowledge the day after I was examined at the Mansion House—my view of my instructions was certainly not that I was to go up to Scotland to commit a fraud; to bring a lot of people into a meeting to pretend

that they are shareholders when they are not is a thing done every day in London—it is certainly not what should have been done: it is done 80 often here that you get quite used to it—I am not personally so often entrusted with messages of that sort that I get quite used to it, but I hear so much about it—I had never done it before—it did not strike me as a very extraordinary thing that I should be asked to do it—I did not go to Scotland for the express purpose of carrying this out; that was a detail—I carried it out, but the chief duty I had to do was to interview shareholders and make them friendly to the board, and I did so—there had been an opposition going on to the board for some months before then—as soon as I arrived in Glasgow, the first man I interviewed told me they had been holding meetings—there was already considerable agitation—I had £25 in my hands to go to Scotland—I was to go and engage the room, not to see the shareholders and stop there till the meeting; I was running about between Glasgow and Edinburgh—I was to stop in Scotland till the meeting—I went on the 6th, the meeting was on the 10th—I received instructions two or three days before I had to go, about the 3rd—I knew I should have to stop there a week, any
how; I did stop a day or so, and I had to stand treat; a little detail—I got there on the morning of the 7th; I travelled all night—the first thing I did was to interview, before 11 o'clock in the morning, a share-holder in the western end of Glasgow; one of our largest shareholders—I went to Glasgow first—I wired to London the result of the interview with that gentleman—he gave me some particulars of what had been going on—I next saw another shareholder in Glasgow—I went to Edin
burgh n the afternoon, and saw some more shareholders there—on the Saturday morning I took the room—the office I had was not large enough to hold a meeting in, and I took Dowell's room—I paid either two or three guineas for it, and I had to get a commissionaire also to assist me at the door, whom I also had to pay—I stopped at an hotel in Edinburgh—on the Sunday afternoon, the 8th, I was running backwards and forwards con
tinually—I went between Edinburgh and Glasgow possibly three or four times, it is only about an hour's journey—I put up at relatives, at Glasgow—at Edinburgh I had to stop at an hotel—I was instructed to make the Royal Hotel, Edinburgh, my headquarters for letters from London—the first day I tried to get these non-shareholders to come over from Glasgow was on the Saturday—the meeting was held on Monday, the 10th—I did not see these various people personally, and make the arrangements with them—I told someone to get a lot of men for the purpose: his name is Leopold Rombach—I had known him years before—as a matter of fact he had a large boarding house, and a number of men in the place were made useful for the purpose; they were quite willing to go over to Edinburgh for the express purpose at the rate of 10s. each—I. believe I said 15 or 16 yesterday came over, but I am more inclined to say that there were 18 or 19—I had to pay all their fares, and 10s. each—that was the instruction I had before I left—my friend was simply one of the men—he was the leader of the band—I cannot tell you personally whether or not any of these people I say were present voted; I was at the door; I am inclined to may that they did; their instructions were to do so—Mr. Rombach was one of those scattered about the room inside—the principal part of my occupation was to stand at the door to prevent the

Press coming in, and shareholders who had decided practically to break up the meeting—there were some people coming in who were not share holders—I could not stop the shareholders coming in—what went on at the meeting I could not attend to very particularly—I stood ia an ante
room by the door, just to keep the passage clear, and the meeting was going on inside the room—those people I brought over from Edinburgh at 10s. each had a full dress rehearsal the night before, and they know what to do—they were not brought over the night before and stayed at Edinburgh, they stayed at the house where they lived; they came on by the 8 o'clock train in the morning—I could not attend to two duties at once, and I did not see that they did what I hired them to do—beyond Rombach I do not think I know the name of one of them—Bombach lived at Homehead Street—I do not think he is alive now; I heard of his death recently—one of the men who voted at the meeting met me in the Strand the other day; he remembered me—there is one man who can corroborate the story I have told—I forget his name for the moment—I remember him at the meeting—I do not know his address—they were strangers to me—I cannot tell you the name of any single living person who saw me pay that 10s. a head to them—I did it in Princes Street, Edinburgh, after the meeting was over, in the street, where everybody could see, if they had chosen to see it—it was the main thoroughfare—the whole 17 or 18 did not march in a band after me; they grouped at a certain place, and as they came up I paid them—I handed the money to Rombach, and—he looked after it—I do not recollect swearing the affidavit which Was to be used in the liquidation proceed jugs—a petition was presented for the winding up of this company in Scotland; it was carried through, and I made an affidavit in answer to it, very likely; I do not remember now—this meeting was packed by more people than myself—the opposition also hnd the meeting packed; it was to counteract the influence of the other side—the instructions I got were to counteract the influence of the other side; I was to get as many friendly shareholders as I could—I never drafted an affidavit; it was drafted for me by the then solicitors for the company, Beall and Co.—it it was sworn by me—those were the figures that were given to me—I was not in the room—I knew a Mr. John Stewart Gowans; he was not a shareholder; he was an accountant, who came in and acted against the board—Mr. Archibald Oliver was also not a shareholder—those two had the most to sty at the meeting—Mr. Gowans proposed an amend
ment to the resolution which had been proposed by the chairman—I cannot tell the wording of it, but it was hostile to the chairman—the affidavit was not drafted by me—if it has been sworn, I certainly have sworn it—if I also said: "Messrs. Gowans and Oliver were also accom
panied with other persons who forced their way into the meeting, although they held no shares; the votes in favour of the directors by proxy were far in excess of those held by Messrs. Gill, Gowans, aud Oliver"; that was also from figures supplied to me—the directors could carry whatever' they liked, but the proxies might not be at the meeting—the proxy is given lor the purpose of being used, but if you hold a proxy it is not as good as having the men there themselves—if you have a lot of hostile people against you, yoii have a lively meeting, but the people in London did not want a disturbance; they were not hostile; they supported the

chairman—they were not hofttileontheother side, like these people; they were clamorous—my friends did not say, "Hear, hear," or make some dis
turbance; they just went like that—that wag all they had instructions to do—we had notice of a number of bona fide shareholders who supported Mr. Gill and Mr. Gowans; it is impossible to say how many were pre
sent, I could (not notice, I was not in the room, but I could hear the uproar from the door—the meeting lasted, possibly, an hour to an hour and a-half—I went to tell the largest shareholders we had that they were going to be paid a cash dividend—Mr. Beall had told me that—the chairman never said a word about the payment of a cash dividend; I was as much surprised as anyone to hear it—the clamour had not commenced till the chairman's speech had pretty well closed—I never drafted an affidavit—when I was before the Magistrate I never said one word about this—I heard the chairman distinctly say that there was only to be a division of ahares, from the door, and that the shares were to be divided as a bonus to the shareholders—he told them that the shares they did hold were to be divided up; each was to get his share of it, his bonus in the way of ahares which he held—someone asked whether there would be a cash dividend, and I believe he said there would be no question of that—iour days before the meeting I was to go and tell the shareholders that there would be a cash payment, whereas when they came to the meeting there would be no statement of the kind, but only a statement as to a division of shares as a bonus to the shareholders; a parcel of shares, 56,000 or 58,000, we held; a lot was under negotiation with a City house—that was the message I had to tell the people—if the shares had been sold there would have been a cash dividend—at the time the cor
poration was wound up, or a petition presented, I do not think there were any trade creditors—the bank owed nothing, only a quarter's rent—a number of things in the way of fitting up in the bank were new, or practically new, and nothing was required to be replaced, so we had no debts—Messrs. Abbott's report was provided to the shareholders; they came to the meeting with a copy of the accounts in their hands, and a report—I take it to be Abbott's; they passed me at the, door with a report and accounts in their hands, and it was that report that made them hostile—during the last year or two there have been disputes between me and Mr. Beall.

Cross-examined by ME. GRAIN. I made Mr. Singleton's acquaintance somewhere about 1890—I became his clerk—as far as I can say, he was conducting the business of an outside broker, dealing in shares—I knew he was not a member of the Stock Exchange, or anything of that sort—I first heard of the proposed launching of the London and Scottish Bank about the time the company was registered, about August, 1892—I knew it was proposed to launch this company; a month or two before August, 1892, probably—I never saw this agreement of March 24th, 1892—the signature is not mine; the handwriting here is partly mine—where the filling up and writing comes in it is filled up by me—this A. F. Baker in the right hand corner is not mine—the name is also up in the corner here—it is not signed by me—I know Singleton's writing very well—I do not say that that is signed by him—it is scarcely the same aignature that he usually used—it is very close to his signature, but I would not bind myself to say that it is his—I would not bind myself to

lay either way—I should pay it was the signature of Singleton before he had properly got into the way of signing the signature of Raker—I be
lieve it to be; it is like it in that fashion—I have signed the name of Baker all my life, and no one else—I never did sign "A.F. Baker"—I am absolutely prepared to say that, that is not in writing—the thing is certain—I tilled it up, but did not see it signed—I cannot remember where I filled it up—I do not remember the document at all, but I know the signature is not mine—I see my own filling up—I do not know what I did with it when I had filled it up—up to the time of my hearing of the proposed flotation of the Scottish Bank I had never known Mr. Singleton to use the name of Baker, I do not think he did—I cannot explain why he adopted the name of Baker, which is my name, and with one of my initials transposed, or why he forgot what the initials were later on—on one occasion he signed "Arthur Francis," and on another "Alexander Frederick," but up to the time of the hearing of the proposed flotation of the bank I had never heard him use the name of Baker; that is true—when I heard of the proposed flotation I may have asked him to do his best to get me appointed secretary—I do not remember I have said that Mr. Beall approached me on the point—they were continually together in 1892—I do not suppose I ever asked for the position of secretary; I may have asked Singleton to get me a billet, to get me appointed to some position, and ultimately I was appointed to the post I held—I was in hopes that this bank would be something of a permanent nature, that something good would turn up, and up to the tune of my appointment there was nothing to raise any suspicion as to the proposed bank—after March 17th, 1893, Mr. Singleton did not take any substantial part in the affairs of the bank—he was there probably from eight to ten days, until we got a clearing bank arranged for—he occasionally came to the bank after that; we saw him frequently—I was assisted by him in performing the duties that I undertook—that was previous to the allotment—he did give some suggestion as to how I should open the books, how I should do it as a clerk in the bank—that is all he did; he had no duty in the bank at all after the company went to allotment.

Cross-examined by MR. MARSHALL HALL. I have been connected with this company from its inception in 1892—I had known Mr. Beall a couple of years or so prior to that—I had been working with Mr. Singleton, who was acting for Mr. Beall—I knew nothing of Mr. Lambert at all until I first saw him in connection with the matters of this bank—it is not to my knowledge that Mr. Lambert was introduced to Mr. Beall by Mr. Humpage in February, 1893, but I know Mr. Humpage used to come about the bank at that time—about a month before the signa
tories appointed the directors I first saw Mr. Lambert there—he acted as a director, and attended a large number of meetings—he was put down for Wednesday at 12 o'clock, and Mr. Wain for Thursday, to attend at the bank for any business that might be wanted, not board meetings, and Mr. Lambert did attend to that part of the work—I was very seldom brought in touch with Mr. Lambert at all, but he knew that I was acting as secretary, because my name appeared—I saw very little of him indeed—he had nothing to do with the correspondence—you may exclude Lam
bert from the direct instructions—the first founders' account of any im
portance was that of the April 18th minute—Mr. Stokes and Mr. Lambert

were appoiuted a hub
coninjittee to go into the accounts—that was a sub-committee for the purpose of vouching the accounts as presented by the founders—I have no reason to doubt that, as far as they were able to vouch them from the figures, they did so vouch them, and found them correct—I happened to be in the board-room the day the accounts were presented, and Mr. Stokes and Mr. Lambert handed these things over, and said they had found them practically accurate—that being so, assuming the document of March 10th, 1892, was a binding document in favour of the promoters, the minute which was the sanction for the pay
ment by Limbert and Stokes was less than they were legally entitled to—there has been a big deduction; so that, so far as the entry of the company or the shareholders is concerned, the passing a resolution in favour of passing the accounts was in favour of the shareholders, according to the agreement—Mr. Stokes was late Her Britannic Majesty's Consul—I have not seen him since he left us in 1895; I do not know if he is alive or not—Mr. Greville is a solicitor; he is alive; I saw him the other day—you could make poor Mr. Stokes practically do any
thing he was wanted to—Mr. Greville was there pretty frequently; he acted for several of the clients with whom the bank carried on discount operations—the next item of account is that furnished for the purpose of declaring the interim dividend; the figures were before the board for some time—I do not know what part the board in a body took—when I gave my evidence before the liquidator there was no question that I was liable, either civilly or criminally—four or five years have elapsed, and now a very serious question has been raised, imputing criminal liability to there people in the dock—I have been seen by the Treasury authorities and by Mr. Gray and others—I am trying to do my best to give you a true account of what took place in October, 1893, when this account was presented—it is more probable that I should have been more accurate in my memory in 1895 than I am in 1899—I was asked, "Did the four directors, before they authorised the payment of this 7 per cent, dividend take any means to satisfy theinselves that the profit had really been earned? (A.) Cer
tainly. I know the chairman before the dividend was paid had the statement in his hands for a week. (Q.) Can you say whether any investigation was made? (A.) I understand there was investigation. (Q.) What investigation? (A.) I cannot throw my memory back so far;"so far as Mr. Lambert was concerned; I never received any difficulty of any kind whatever from him as to the answering of any figures in this account—I cannot say how far Mr. Lambert knew of the figures, but I received no instructions from him—I was satisfied that at that time, at any rate, he was doing his duty as a director to the Scottish Bank; the staff knew that he was connected with other companies, and we looked upon him as quite a Martinet—it was Mr. Lambert that I had to deal with on its staff being guaranteed—there was some delay in the guarantee going through—Mr. Lambert applied to me week after week to see if the Guarantee Society had accepted the proposal; finally, Mr. Lambert instructed me to take steps to have each man of the staff separately guaranteed—we had a directors' attendance book—I know he did not attend the meeting in Edinburgh—it was his intention to go to Scotland, but it may have oeen illness that stepped in—he did not go—

I heard from Messrs. Abbott that Mr. Lambert said it was not a question of valuation by the directors, but a question of taking the securities at their par value, and it ought to be stated; that was Mr. Lambert's intention, I know—I know there was a very strong interview between Mr. Lambert and Mr. Abbott on that—Mr. Wain resigned on December 14th, according to the minutes—that would of itself have dissolved the board, because there would be only one director then—I do not believe there was after December 5th a properly constituted board meeting—those letters that were written after the Scottish meeting were written; without Mr. Lambert's knowledge—I do not remember that some cheques were submitted to Mr. Lambert about that time for his signature which he declined to sign—the letter from me in which I offer founders' shares for sale was a private matter of my own—I do not suggest that Mr. Lambert knew anything about that; I was not selling the shares privately; I was assisting the promoters, of which Mr. Lambert was not one—we used to send letters out frequently, but they were written on the instructions of the promoters—Mr. Lambert had nothing to do with them; he had nothing to do with the founders', and the founders' had nothing to do with the bank; because all the founders' were allotted to Baker and his nominees—so far as I knew, Lambert never received any money at the bank in any way except for directors' fees—anything he had from the bank has been repaid, and in addition he had lent the bank money—the bank were his debtors at the date of the liquidation; he had nothing whatever to do with my going to Scotland, or anything of that kind—I have had a great deal to do with this company, from start to finish—I will admit that I had a great deal more to do with it than ever Mr. Lambert has had—so far as I know, there has never been any proposition made to include me in a criminal charge with regard to this matter.
Wednesday. November 8th.

FREDERICK JOHN BAKER (Recalled) (Cross-examined by MR. A. GILL). Mr. Wain had nothing to do with the issue of founders' shares, to my knowledge, or with the correspondence with the persons who pur
chased shares—that was a matter between the promoters and the persons who bought—Wain came on other occasions beside the board days—he used to come in occasionally when he was passing in the neighbourhood—I cannot say that Wain never received a shilling of promotion money in connection with this company—the signature in this letter to Messrs. Abbott (Exhibit 238) is not mine—it is per pro Mr. Colee, the cashier; I was in Scotland at this time—it was written by Mr. Colee for me, who was acting as secretary in my absence—I see in Messrs. Abbott's report (Exhibit 223), under the head of promotion account, the item, "Account presented by W. J. C. Wain, Esq., £313 13s."; that is the sum the directors paid to Mr. Wain for office furniture in Paris—the furniture belonged to the European company who were former tenants of the office, and when the bank took the office in Paris they paid Mr. Wain for the furniture—I now remember that the amount which Wain had paid out in connection with the Paris office between December, when the agreement took effect, and the allotment in March was agreed at £469—against that there were

certain payments which the bank had made on behalf of the European company—I cannot remember that now, but the minute says so—I do not remember receiving this letter (Produced)—I did not open the whole of the correspondence—it is addressed to the secretary—it would be received at the bank, but I did not open the correspondence in the instructions to me; it is dated August 1st, 1894—(Read: "Dear Sirs,—The asuditors have seen me to
day. It is most essential that you ihould be in London on Tuesday, so that the audit may be proceeded with without delay. Personally, I shall be present, so as to give all the assistance that may be necessary. Please have all securities ready for production, register of debentures, and everything the auditors may require, including the paying
in book cf the London and Midland Bank, and the 'Founders' Shares Numerical Register'")—there was no such book kept in the office as the "Founders' Shares Numerical Register"—the founders' shares belonged to the promoters; the bank had nothing to do with the numerical list; that would be in the possession of the promoters—I know Mr. Wain went to America in 1894; I cannot say if it was in September and October—he was away for a considerable period about the time that the auditors were examining the books—I thiuk it was two or three days before December 6th that I went to Scotland to attend the meeting—it was not done in a hurry—I did not get instructions in the afternoon and leave that night—Beall gave me instructions—there was a second party undoubtedly there at the time, but I cannot identify him at the time—I was asked if I could provide a number of men in Edinburgh; I said I was a stranger there, I did not know anybody in Edinburgh, but I could do it in Glasgow—I knew that Wain was going to be the chairman of the meeting—I had some conversation at the hotel on the 10th with Beall on the landing, that was right outside my door—he came at 7 o'clock in the morning—with regard to what took place in the breakfast
room, I am giving my recollection after five years to the best of my ability, as to what I said to Wain—I said I had a number who would support him, and we talked about the interviews I had had with shareholders as well—I called upon shareholders in Scotland and promised them a cash dividend—they were present undoubtedly; they intended to be present whether they had seert me or not—nothing was said about 130 per cent, cash dividend—there was quite an uproar when the chairman spoke about 125 per cent, in shares—my instructions were simply to call on people who held 40 shares, the larger holders of shares—40 was about as many as are issued to anyone, and I called on six or seven of them in Glasgow—they were all present—I remember that a report was read—the shareholders came to the door with a report and balance-sheet in their possession—I did not hear Wain's speech—I was busy at the door—as to the interim dividend of October, 1893, any alteration that was made in the account upon which that was baaed was made in the board-room—it was prepared by me and handed to the directors—it was not a report—it was a rough draft of a balance-sheet, simply figures; it did not show a profit—I never suggested that any alteration had been made by Wain or any other director—I caunot recollect what I did say, but I know what took place perfectly well—I did not prepare a document showing the valuation of

the bonuses; all I did was to make a statement of the entries from the bank books of the sums we received and sams we have paid out, and there was a slip showing a detailed statement of the items in the acouunt—there was no attempt made even to make a balance of it—Wain's fees as director amounted to about £200, or rather more—the directors' attendance book would show it—I do not think he was paid for the later at
tendances; he held 40 ordinary shares in the company, which he paid for—that would be £200, so that he has lost.

Re-examined. I do remember the minute of March 28th, which has been read a few minutes ago to me: "Resolved on the solicitor's advice that the bank do pay to the European Commercial and Industrial Com
pany the amount of £330, being half year's rent of Paris office paid in advance by European company (£90), with £240, price of furniture, fix
tures, and fittings as per vouchers produced; cheque for £320 granted"—this is the counterfoil of that cheque dated March 28th—there are entries in red ink on it—the cheque is not there; that is only the counterfoil—it is dated March 28th, "half-year's rent Paris office," 9,000 it looks like, but it is £90," Office furniture, £240"; and then there ii some pencil here—that is £330; the writing on this counterfoil dated March 28th for £330 is Beall's Wa—Exhibit 163 it an account of the Lon
don and Scottish Bank with the London and Midland Bank, April 4th, Paris office, £330; that is the same cheque—in the ledger, No. 5, I find there an account in the name of Mr. J. O. Wain: "March, 1893, promo
tion expenses, £469 5s."—that is to the credit of Mr. Wain; that is dis
charged, August 16th, 1893, cash £10, £25, £100, and so on; and then Promotion Account, European Company, £114 16s., September 7th. Cleme, £18, ditto £12 16s.; Chevaleau, £10; November 28th, W. J. Carruthers Wain, £103 13s.—that is how by those dates the £469 for promotion expenses is cleared off—when the persons came into the room they had reports with them—I cannot say what they were like—they came with two papers, but I did not examine the papers—I did not take the papers from their hands and read them—they satisfied me, by having those papers in their hands, that they were shareholders, and I did not read the documents—before I went up to Scotland I had instructions from Beall—Wain was at the office on the day I had those instructions—the cashier was called into the room and instructed to give me £25—in the cash-book it is "December 6th, by cheque, F. J. Baker, £30"; I had £25—it was not a cheque; it was cash—the affidavits that were sworn by me were drafted by whoever was solicitor for the com
pany at the time—during the existence of the bank there were three firms of solicitors that acted for us—I went away on the even
ing of the 6th, and I got that money that afternoon—the affidavit was prepared by Beall—Brandon and Nicholson are the solicitors here, but it was prepared by Beall; his notes are here—both these affidavits were prepared and settled by Beall—when Mr. Stokes and Mr. Greville resigned I think it was early in 1894—I always believed the share-, in these London and British Refuse Companies to be valuable from the general conversation in the office—we knew Mr. Cooper, who had treat faith in the future of the company; we were in the habit of meeting him generally from the board—I had no knowledge of the matter—njy opiuion was merely what I heard—I see in the minute of

June 23rd, 1893: "Correspondence from Paris was produced, and the resignation of the committee, and also the chairman's replies to Mr. Brandreth as to Giving up the French offices, and instructions were given the manager in Paris not to arrange for the appointment of any fresh committe"; andon June 27th, 1893, I "see this entry: "Present, Wain, Mr. Stokes and Lambert, directors; and Mr. Brandon, Solicitor: Re the French offices" at thai end of the minute: "It was resolved that they be continued for a short time longer. No committee to be at present appointed, and the staff to devote their time to the sale of the company's shares"—then on July 4th, "The resignation of the conn mittee of the Paris office was considered and accepted, and it was re
gretted that they did not inform the London board previously of their inability to introduce business of a profitable character; and the repre
sentations under which the French offices were opened not having been carried out, it was resolved that steps be taken to close the same and the staff be discharged; "and at the end of that minute there is, "The directors took into consideration the various letters and communications from the Paris office; and having regard to the fact that none of the promises originally held out had been fulfilled, and that no business whatever had been transacted, it was proposed by Mr. Greville and seconded by Mr. Stokes, and carried unanimously, 'That steps be taken to close the Paris offices, discharge Mr. Brandreth, and, if necessary, the staff. Mr. Brandon (solicitor to the company) is hereby empowered to take the necessary steps to carry out tliis resolution, and to that end a power of attorney be executed in his favour, and that he be requested to proceed forthwith to Paris'"—in the minute of August 29th, 1893, "Present, Mr. Carruthers Wain, Mr. Lambert, Mr. Stokes,. Mr. Gre
ville. Mr. Brandon, solicitor, also attended"—towards the end there is this: "A cheque for Mr. A. Brandreth was also ordered to be drawn for £250, and it was reported that he had withdrawn his action on the terras of the following letter, viz., '3 and 4, Great Winchester Street, London, E.C., August 23rd, 1893. To the Directors of the London and Scottish Banking and
Discount Corporation, Limited. Gentlemen—In considera
tion of the settlement of the action brought by me against your corpora
tion, the teims of which have been agreed upon, I hereby undertake to discontinue all litigation against your corporation or yourselves person
ally, also to withdraw my opposition to your obtaining possession of the premises at 20, Rue St. George's, Paris, lately occupaied by the corpora
tion; and further, not to communicate to the public Press, either in England or elsewhere, any information that may be detrimental or in
jurious to the corporation or its directors personally—Yours faithfully ALFRED B, BHANDRETH '"—when I prepared tjie statement which was sent in to the directors with reference to the payments and receipts before the 7 per cent, dividend was declared I had a discussion about one of the entries for directors' fees with Wain and Beall—if the directors' fees had not been charged for the first half-year it would have shown a profit—at that time only £5 per share had been called up, and the amount of capital they had to work with was a small one—the directors' fees had been paid; they were paid each board meeting—so far ns I remember, it was agreed that the half-year should be charged with this expenditure in that fashion; they could not withdraw the amount

from the accounts—a. profit was to be brought out by adding some of the bonus shares that would fall to the bank for the work, that the board. did—they had financed the Sheridans at that time—they were going to get bonuses in addition for assisting those people—the bonuses were to be. shares in the business the Sheridans were going through at the time.

RICHARD SCOTT AITCHESON . I am a chartered accountant, of Edin
burgh, and was appointed official liquidator to the London Scottish Banking Corporation on January 16th, 1895—I came up to London about January 18th or 19th to the office of the bank, 35, Lombard Street, where I took possession of such of the books and documents as I could get—I think I mentioned at the Mansion House that I saw Wain there, but on referring to my notes afterwards I found that I did not see him at the bank on that occasion; I tried to arrange two meetings with him, aud he disappointed me on both occasions; but I saw Lambert afterwards, not at the bank, but at the hotel—I also arranged that Lambert should be at the bank meeting, but he did not come up; I saw Beall as the bank, I did not see him on the first occasion, I saw F. J. Baker—I had been up once before; I was formally appointed liquidator—I did not collect any books before I was formally appointed—I only came up once for the purpose of collecting the books—I had the assistance of a clerk from the office of Clarke, Rawlins and Co.—I was not acquainted with the English style of doing business, so I got the assistance of a clerk—I made a list, which is—Exhibit 252, of tho books which I had possession of, and which I after
wards handed over to the Director of Public Prosecutions; it was a list made when the books were sent up to him—the letter-books which I got began with letter-book No. 3—I never saw letter-books 1 and 2—letter-book No. 3 commences with March 14th, 1893—I never had any share-holders' ledger, or a list or account of any sort of the holders of founders' shares—I never saw any account of the founders' shares at all—I never saw any minutes of the meetings of the signatories prior to the appointment of directors or governors or any agreement of March 10th, 1892—I did not find among the papers any account showing the position of the company at the date when the 7 per cent, dividend was declared—the petty cash in hand was £10s. 8d—at my instigation the directors and F. J. Baker and Mr. Beall were examined in Scotland b fore Lord Stormonth
Darling in February, 1895—shorthand notes were taken of their examination—I was present the whole time of their examination, and I have since checked the transcript of the shorthand notes—I do not say that that transcript produced is a correct transcript of the evidence given by Lambert, Wain, and Beall—that is the actual transcript I checked, and it is certified by Lord Stormonth
Darling as correct—I did early in my appointment communicate with Messrs. Abbott, who had audited the books—I obtained from them a copy of their report and balance-sheet, and also some books—I prepared from the books and from Messrs. Abbott's balance-sheet a bal
ance-sheet up to January 16th, 1895, the date of my appointment—Exhibit 253 is the balance-sheet which I prepared, with a profit and loss account from March 31st, 1894, to January 10th, 1895—the profit and loss account shows £2,739 odd—my profit and loss account shows that the total amount earned in that, period was £152 1s.—I think there was tid., toomuch, and did not go back over the older account; I took Messrs. Abbott's account for

that—that was the total amount earned by interest, discount, and commission—during that period the directors' fees on the other side of the account amounted to £389 odd; salaries, including the financial manager, £l,012; law charges, etc., £698; and the rent and other expenses are divided up—the financial manager does not take all the £1,012; It is divided: office staff £687 6s., and financial manager £325; then there is rent and other expenses, making a total of £2,891 13s. 8d.—I did accept Messrs. Abbott's balance-sheet up to 1894 as correct, and, taking Messrs. Abbott's balance-sheet as accurate up to March, 1894, my balance-sheet shows a total loss during the working of this corporation of £11,755—the total loss on the whole working is £11,755 14s. 4d.—from my examination of the accounts I could find no justification whatever for the declaration of this 7 per cent, dividend or any other dividend—I saw that a total sum of £29 10s. had been received in the shape of premiums on the second issue of shares, and that second issue was at 10s. premium, so that that represented over 59 shares—with regard to the debenture stock I found traces of one person only, a lady, having applied for deben
ture stock—that was to the amount of £200—I found among the docu
ments the certificate that has been produced for the 30,000 London Refuse shares, and also the certificate for a further 15,000 shares in the London Refuse Company—I did not receive or collect at all any certificates of shares in the British Company—having collected the documents which represented assets of the company, I made a valuation of them in the first place—all these shares, I think, I valued at £50—my valuation of the total of the assets was £786 odd—the shares I put down at £50—that included some other shares besides the London Refuse and British Refuse Companies—Exhibit 251 contains a list of the assets of the bank, and in the result I realised £336 4s. 9d. from the whole of the assets, which includes calls unpaid on shares which I got in—I tried to realise these shares in the Refuse Company—I could not get anything at all for them—I found among the shares which were represented as assets some Buenos Ayres Tram shares—I found that those shares had been deposited as security for a debt—those were not properly included in the list of bonus shares—they were, in fact, included in the list of bonus shares representing a total of £48,000—that particular loan had been repaid before I was appointed—I find 100 £5 shares in the Lam
bert Collieries; received from 0. Hendrof £250—they were not properly included in the list of bonus shares, because J was informed afterwards that they were divided between Mr. F. J. Baker and Mr. Beall; between the assistant-secretary and Mr. Beall—I never got them—there are two bracketed together: "Five shares, founders', and 100 shares, ordinary; Olympic Music Hall (in liquidation), received from Shenton, no value"—the third one here is Wallace's acceptance for £300, which is put in the balance
sheet—the balance is made up of these items—in the minute of May 29th, 1894, I see "Re V. W. Wallace. A letter was read from Beall and Co., stating that a receiving order has been made against this person"—I cannot say whether I found this document (Produced)—I found in the books an entry with regard to shares in this London Refuse Company—at the examination of Beall before Lord Stormonth-Darling something was said about 5,000 London Refuse shares—I did not examine the books to ascertain whether

any shares in the London Refuse Company had been transferred to him, Beall—I understood the London and Scottish Bank were entitled to 50,000 shares in the London Refuse Company—I only got documents to the extent of 30,000 and 15,000, and the other 5,000 went to Mr. Beall, for services rendered.

Cross-examined by MR. ISAACS. I came up to London before I was appointed liquidator, on December 26th, on an order of the Court—there was a petition presented on the Record before the Court, and on that there was a conflicting opposition, and then the Court ordered me to go down to the bank and make some report—I came up here in order to inquire, and when appointed liquidator I employed Messrs. Clarke and Rawlins, the solicitors, to act for us in London—I had nothing to do with Messrs. Davidson and Syme, and I had no solicitors at all when I came up the first time—I first went to the bank on the 27th—it was closed on the day I came up, the 26th—I went there in the morning, and stated what I had come for—I saw Mr. F. J. Baker—I was informed that Mr. Beall was away at Brighton ill—I got a certificate from his doctor in the beginning of January—I had no reason to doubt that Mr. Beall was at Brighton ill—in January he came back—it was about January 23rd that he came back—in December, 1894, when I was in Scotland, I was told that the persons, that is, Mr. Glaskin or high officials in connection with the London Refuse Destructor, would be asked to meet me to explain what had been done and what was being done—Mr. Glaskin was the con
sulting engineer in December—I did not see them; I was told that they were there, but I did not want to see them; I made no engagement with them—I understood about this balance-sheet of Messrs. Abbott; I knew that one of the assets which, at any rate, the Scottish Bank claimed to have were the shares in these Refuse Destructor companies—I was making inquiries in other quarters as to the balance-sheet—it did not occur to me that those were the best people to tell exactly what was being done with regard to it, as I wanted an independent witness—so far as these shares were concerned, there was no market value or Stock Exchange quotation—my reason for not seeing the people who were actually working the thing was that I wanted evidence outside the directors of the London and Scottish Bank—I never did, in fact, see either Mr. Glaskin or Mr. Cheesewright—I saw Mr. Cooper about it at his office, and I saw Mr. Wain about it—although the certificate did not come into my hands, I satisfied myself as to the title of the Scottish Bank to the £16,500 British; that is to say, that the Scottish Bank was entitled to the shares, although they had not got the certificate in their hands—ultimately I got all the books and papers except a shareholders' ledger—I know-a shareholders' ledger was kept, and I am almost sure I must have seen one iu December; when I came and took possession it was not there—so far as the ledger is concerned, it would be a register of ordiuary shares—the shareholders' ledger was of this importance, that I could" not tell who were in arrear, it is only to ascertain who had not paid the calls; I got £23—I had to get my clerk to make up a complete statement of the calls, and I found several inarrear—I came up later on in January, and employed Messrs. Clarke and Rawlins as solicitors—when I came on the scene in January, 1895, I

found the balance-sheet, wbich had been made out, and upon which the litigation had arisen which had given me the appointment, and, so far as that was concerned, which had been made out by Messrs. Abbott and certified by them, I accepted that as correct; then, as they had only worked up the figures to March 31st, 1894, dealing with the year previous, to it, I set to work to see what the figures showed from March 31st, 1894, to January, 1895—I found that the interest, discount, and commission amounted to £152 only—the discount, commission, and interest from March 31st, 1894, to January, 1895, were considerably less than they had been after the corresponding period of the previous year, which showed that that part of the business was less from March, 1894, to January, 1895; there was no money to lend—the greater part of the money left had been used with regard to the Atlas Syndicate—£2,885 had been used by the Atlas Syndicate in the promotion of the London Refuse Destructor, and instead of having liquid assets fo work with, what they had got were these shares which they had received instead—this item, "Auditor's fees, £126," was paid to Messrs. Abbott for writing up the books and preparing the balance-sheet, I understand, then there are other items which bring the figure for that nine months up to £2,739 loss—the loss for the whole period was £11,755, made up of three items shown in the balance-sheet, which give no credit of any kind for the bonus shares, but if I took that £11,459, which was apparently the cash loss for the year Irom March 31st, 1893, to March 31st, 1894, I show a cash loss of £11,459; with the dividend it makes up the £11,755, which is the loss; that is how I got at it—as to these Buenos Ayres Tr urns, Abbott's ledger states: "100 shares Buenos Ayres Tram Ways Company and charges on interest on 2,000 shares in the London Metallurgical Company (in liquidation), J. Stewart Boyle, liquidator, received from C. A. Reeve," and there is another one here: "45 shares £5 paid preference in Buenos Ayres Tram Company, received from J.W. Clarke"—that is the one I was referring to—it is Clarke's account—there are two lots of shares, amongst which there are 45 Buenos Ayres Trams—the whole lot realised £800—the entry I have just read and some other shares are taken in en bloc without any sum being put to them—some items are estimated, and some are not, and the whole amount alto
gether is taken in at £1,700, which is composed of the figures which are inserted in the columns against the shares—Messrs. Abbott have taken Wallace's acceptance into account at £300—that is their figure down here—it was they who did that from the books.

Cross-examined by MR. MARSHALL HALL.—I tried to realise this estate with my usual judgment, to the best of my ability—the only interest I had was to get the assets in from a professional point of view, to their est advantage—the estate is not wound up yet—I mean there was no immediate hurry—with regard to the 300 Grappler Tyre shares, valued here at £300, I got a valuation on the whole shares—I do not know that the shares which were realised in this liquidation at something like 3s. 6d. a share, sold within twelve months at something like £5 a share in the open market in 1896; free buyers—we believe in Irish tyres—I was not told that these shares were of great value, and ought to be held—I have already said that I know nothing of the shares being

freely quoted at £4 10s. and £5 witbin twelve months of this time—I cannot say that I ever heard that until you suggested it to-day—I will swear I did not—my attention has never been called to the value of those shares—I had heard of it at the Mansion House; I thought you meant, did I know from my own personal knowledge—I did not take up the attitude of treating this thing as a fraud from beginning to end, and refusing;; to listen to any advice on the subject at all—if you take the Grappler shares, for example, I got the opinion of a first-class firm here in London on the subject, Messrs. Faithful! Begg and Co.; they are members of the Stock Exchange—they valued the whole shares—I could not ask the stockbroker to go and value each thing separately—I have not sold the Grappler shares; I could not, they did not belong to the company—I did not say at the Mansion House that I sold them—I never had the certificate—I took the shares as appearing in the list of assets; Abbott's list—he said he had satisfied himself that these belong to the company—this valuation is by Faithfull Begg and Co.: Mr. Begg, M.P.—I made further inquiries—"which would take—considerable time and involve corresponding expenses, which we are-not justified in incurring without definite authority. We are of opinion that a lew hundred pounds at the very outside is the utmost that could be realised by the sale of the whole of the securities. The majority of them we regard as absolutely without any value whatever"; now my point is this, how could I have sold those 300 Grappler shares for between £1,460 and £1,500 when I had not thecerti
ficate?—that is the very reason why I got these directors to Edinburgh, to-get the certificate—I brought an action to get it—I had the directors before the Scottish Court—I asked Mr. Lambert where the certificate was—I never communicated with the Grappler Tyre Co.—I did not write to the Grappler Tyre Co. and ask them whether this corporation were on the register of the company as the proprietors of these shares, after the explanation made by these directors in Edinburgh—it was informa
tion I got from Mr. Beall and from Mr. Baker—Mr. Lambert was asked for information generally—I cannot say I asked specifically—any
how, I never communicated with the company with regard to it, because after the information I got there was no occasion to—both Baker and Beall were asked about the Grappler—it was simply a security; they never got it registered—I understood it had been a security for a loan, which loan had been repaid, and therefore they were no longer entitled to the shares—I looked up the statement with regard to Beall at the time—Mr. Lambert was in Court, and if he considered the Grappler shares were in existence he should have said so—we had him up there for this very purpose—the directors were examined on February 26th, 1895—it was before that that I submitted these shares for valuation to Faithfull Begg and Co., for the purpose of my report in December—what good was it to go or send to Dublin to ask for information from the Grappler Company, when I was told they were security for a debt?—the directors were there, and if they did not consider it right they should have said so—anyhow, I have never realised those shares, and I never made any inquiries about it—I made inquiries about the other shares other than getting this valuation from Faithfull Begg and Co., from the

brokers in Edinburgh, Scotch brokers—Miss Tilton's was a debenture for £200, charging all the assets of the company—Miss Tilton was not paid because there was no money; she would have a right over costs even—what was realised went in costs.

Re-excamined. I can find nothing to show that the company bad any title to these shares; it was not possible for me to sell them—I asked some Scotch brokers to get information for me on the value of the aecurities—I just sent them the list of those Grappler shares; they informed me that they could get no direct information at the time—I had not got them to sell—I believe the London Refuse Company and the British Refuse Company never went to allotment—I was asked a good many questions about the shareholders' ledger: whether it was in existence, and so on—I never saw any register showing what founders' shares had been issued, and to whom.

WILLIAM ABBOTT . I am one of the firm of William Abbott and Co., chartered accountants—about July of 1894 I was communicated with by a Mr. Weller, and attended at the London and Scottish Bank for the purpose of auditing the accounts—I received instructions when I got there from the directors and Mr. Beall—we saw Mr. Wain and Mr. Lam
bert, and Mr. Beall, from what I remember, and commenced, with the assist
ance of our clerks, an examination of the books—I found from the books the receipt in the shape of subscriptions for the ordinary shares; March 31st was £21,706—I should say, less £2,000 for founders' shares, which I see are treated in the same item; I did not notice that at first—if I put it at £19,706 that will be the correct answer—we found that the moneys first received from the subscriptions, £6,969 10s., had been paid into A. F. Baker's account; that is all in respect of ordinary shares; and payments to the corporation made by Mr. Baker were £5,325 19s. 9d. leaving a balance of £1,642 10s. 3d. unaccounted for—I made inquiries of either of the defendants as to what had become of the balance—we inquired of all of them, I believe—the explanation given by the secretary was that this amount was payments made on behalf of the London and Scottish Bank on pro
motion account by the promoters—we asked for vouchers to show those payments, but never saw any—we asked for an account of The items of these payments; that we never received—the establishment expenses ac
count was put before us; I believe this is it (Produced)—this would undoubtedly be the book from which it appears to be taken—that was in the book at the time we audited—the itein on this account, "Birtwistle, £200," appears in the book when we first examined it, I imagine—that was an amount which had been paid by Mr. Birtwistle for shares—I see our journal note on it is that it was an amount received by Mr. Beail from Mr. Birtwistle for shares in this company prior to the company going to allotment, and it was omitted in the account of the allotment—the money had not been handed over—I cannot remember now; I know it was carried to establishment expenses after I came on the scene, I think—I said I did not quite remember, but I think it might have been so, from the reason that we allude to it in our accounts and owing to the journal entries—in the establishment expenses account 1 find at the end these two items: 'Beall and Co., No. 1 account. £346 19s. 8d.; ditto. No. 2 account, £1,219 10s. 4d."—at the time I came on the scene I found, ac
cording
