to the general ledger, that Beall's account No. 1 was overdrawn to the amount of £346 19s. 8d., and that amount of the overdraft of Beall's account has been transferred to the establishment expenses account—according to the figures before me, Beall and Co. No. 2 account is overdrawn £1,219 10s. 4d.; from the figures in the general ledger, it appears tu be £1,193 138. 10d., or Us. 10d., and in the ledger that is balanced by transferring that overdraft to the establishment expetses account—the account is not ruled off here at all; it is not finished off, but that is the result—the result is to balance it; that is how it was treated—I inquired of Beall himself, and of all the directors, I believe, that is Mr. Wain and Mr. Lambert, and the explanation given to me was that it was to be transferred to the promotion expenses account, for payments made out by Mr. Beall—we had no vouchers before us to show those payments made—it was transferred because it was assumed that the balance appear
ing on that account tobe due to Mr. A.F. Baker was, in fact, due to Mr. Beall—the accounts of Mr. Beall and Mr. Baker were apparently one and thesame almost—we had to take those figures as we found them in the book—we had to work from that minute; we had to take the figures given in the minute that a certain sum had been expended—by the minute of April 18th, when the promoters' account was admitted, "It was resolved to admit the account at the above figure," that is £4,777—this is our note: "No account showing how this amount has been arrived at has been shown to us, although asked for, and we have been simply guided by the minutes "; that is as to the £4,777—I do not think I have the whole of the minute here; this is our journal note—this minute is April 18th—I have an account of all the moneys—we simply started with the balance of £4,777, and then we may have worked out the payments from that, but I do not see that we have got any account to show the difference between £3,409 and £4,777—I cannot make the figures fit, and I do not think, as far as I know, that any of the Counsel have succeeded in doing it—I do not know whether it is important or not, but it is a mystery—I did not say that I accepted this figureof £4,777 balance, and deducting that from the £6,909, I got the other figure; we have nothing to do with the £6,909—the de
duction of £2,132 is by an agreement dated March 10th, 1892, as I understand it; "less deduction from the agreement dated March 10th, 1892": that is the figure they arrived at themselves—we accepted the figure £4,777 from the minute as the balance j we had no means of check
ing it—so far as our figures are concerned, that £2,132 is merely arrived at by subtracting the £4,777 from the £6,909, and by an agree
ment with the directors and the promoters to do so.

By the COURT. "£6,909 had been paid by the promoters"—according to our figures they had retained in their hands £1,642, moneys received from shareholders, which they had not handed over—I am afraid I can give no further explanation now; it is so long ago—at the time possibly there was some fuller explanation, but it looks as though it was an item—our figure of £1,642 never comes into this Establishment Expenses Account at all—there is another one of £1,855 below it, "Amounts paid by A. F. Baker on account," which is a payment made to A. F. Baker on the opposite side; that is a different item of the account—I have all the dates and amount paid in to the credit of the account.

By MR. AVORY, I saw no vouchers of any sort representing the de
duction of £2,132—we saw no vouchers in connection with the account at all, either for the £6,909 or for the £4,777, nor for the £1,855—on November 3rd, 1894, we sent in our report to the directors—this is my report—(This stated that they found the hooks imperfectly kept, and it was therefore necessary for them to write up the accounts of the corpo
poration from March 13th, 1893, to March 31th, 1894; that the liability of the corporation on capital account amounted to £24,264, less calls unpaid at date £2,556, leaving a net amount of £21,706; that they had included in the capital 300 shares applied for in Paris, but upon which nothing had been paid; that several of the moneys received on amplication and allotment first issue, were paid into Mr. A. F Baker's private banking account, and he made several payments on behalf of the corporation out of such moneys; that they had asked for Mr. Baker's account, but it had not been produced; that from the books it appeared the the corporation's moneys paid into Mr. Baker's hanking account amounted to £6,969 10s. and the payments to the corporation made by Mr. Baker amounted to £5,325 19s. 9d., leaving a halance of £1,642 10s. 3d., which the secretary informed them was the amount of payments side on hehalf of the corpora
tion on promotion account, hui as no account had heen presented to them, they were unahle to vouch the accuracy of these payments; and that the suspense account was made up of various unexplained items, including sundry deficiencies of cash; and that they helieved the accounts to be a correct statement of the corporation's affairs)—enclosed with that report I sent the balance-sheet and profit and loss account up to March 31st, 1894—in our profit and loss account, as sent in, we showed that the bank had earned in that period £1,296 198. 6d., and that the expenses were £9,840 3s. 9d., showing a loss of £8,543 4s. dd.—that was when I had taken only one-third of the promotion expenses for that period—that report and profit and loss account being sent in to the directors, I saw both Lambert and Wain upon it—the principal subjects of conversation were with regard to the absence of vouchers and the promoters' accounts, and also as to the bonuses—they requested that bonuses between us and Wain and Lambert should be treated as an item of profit—they asked us to treat them as securities—they presented a list of these things—it was in a book, I think; I have one book with the list in it—this is a copy that I made at the time from list—they said that these shares represented securities held by the bank to the value of £48,200, and that they wanted them to be credited in the account as such; that was stated by Mr. Wain and Mr. Beall—we then put into the account, "By bonuses valued by the directors, but which are subject to realization"—it was while I was preparing our accounts that I had this conversation with Beall and Wain—it was spoken of on several occasions; it was spoken about, I believe, before we made out our profit and loss account, showing the loss at £8,463—I imagine the account would be sent, out with £8,540; the figures would be arrived at afterwards, the grand total—the account would be probably submitted with the £8,543 loss, ami then the question of how these items were to be dealt with would come on—I thought I was speaking of the making up of the list amouuting to £48,200; I should

say that that figure of £48,200 would not be given to us until after we had dealt with the loss, but we should, of course, come across the securities at the time we were going through the account all along—we never put any value upon these securities in the accounts until after we had submitted our draft profit and loss account—after we had submitted our profit and loss account we got the value, the figure of £48,200, from the directors and Mr. Beall—by "the directors" I mean Wain and Lambert—I described them as bonuses because they were received as bonuses for business done, as rewards for certain advances and that kind of thing—we thought it fairer to describe them as bonuses than to use the word "securities"—I have got the copy of our balance-sheet as we sent it in ultimately to the directors—the item occurs in two places at the right-hand side of the balance-sheet, "By bonuses subject to realisation, £48,200"—I have not got a print of it—the print is not as we sent it in; I have it here as I sent it in—I will tell you how it is as we sent it in—it was "By bonuses valued by the directors, but which are subject to realisation," and in the profit and loss account it was repeated—it is the fourth item in the balance-sheet, and in both places in the balance-sheet and the profit and loss account I sent it in with those words—the result of bringing in that £48,200 was to show a net profit of £39,183, subject to the realisation of the bonuses credited per contra—we added in the certificate, "We have examined the foregoing balance-sheet of profit and loss account, and find them to, be in accordance with the books of the corporation in London, and subject to our report of this date, we believe them to be a correct statement of the corporation's affairs"—I did not underline the words, "subject to any. report of this date"—one item is "By investment" in the balance-sheet "£425"—I have detaih to show what those investments are—there are 200 fully paid shares in the District Messenger Company, taken over at £2 each, and in the Union Newspaper Company ordinary shares are taken ovw at £25; that makes the £425—we took them at the price at which they had been taken over, not at what they were worth—I made a stipulation when I sent in this report, with Mr. Wain, I believe, that our report was to be read at the meeting—he promised that it should be done—this letter (231) dated September 2nd, 1894, is addressed to F. J. Baker; that enables me to fix the date when I sent in our draft account—it says: "In accordance with the arrangement made with your directors to
day at our interview with Mr. Lambert, we send herewith copy of the draft accounts we have prepared. We shall be pleased to meet the direc
tors hereon any time on Wednesday morning"—that would be the same account practically, but leaving out these bonus shares, but it is so long ago—I do not remember whether I had put them in by that time or net—No. 233 is the next letter, November 2nd, addressed to Baker, secre
tary (Read)—I then received the letter of December 8th, which has been read by Mr. Arthur Gill—(Further correspondence was put in and read)—we gave Messrs. Lewis a copy of our balance-sheet; we originally drew it—this is it (Produced)—we supplied Mr. Aitohison after h» was appointed with a copy of our original report and balance-sheet.
Cross-examined by MR. ISAACS. I was approached in the first instance by Mr. Weller—he was never in our employ—I did not know him when

he came—I did not know him at all—when I went there some of the work had been already done—this is the establishment expenses account (Produced)—there is no explanatory entry—there is this: "By T. Birtwistle, 40 shans, £5 paid"—all the entries above that are by cheque—"By Birtwistle, 40 shares," shows that 40 £5 shares had been credited, instead of handing the money over, and that I found in the book when I came there—I believe the two items of the overdrawn account are not our entries—I did not find the account balanced up in that way; I am inclined to think this is one of our clerks' writing; it is not my own—I found a minute of April 18th, which stated that the sum of £6,909 had been agreed, to, and that from that sum a balance of £2,132 had been subtracted in order to make the £4,777, and that the figures making up those items had been before a committee of the board, Lambert and Stokes—when I oame on the scene and inquired into these matters was some time in July, 1894—when we came on the scene we raised a great question, but that was the position in which we found it—I do not re
member the date our report was delivered; the papers show it, you have a receipt there showing the date—I do not think we had a cheque, I think cash was paid—we were paid, any way—they brought notes, I think; there was a receipt given by Mr. Pappadaki for the accounts, which was put in—that fixes the identical date—a receipt was put in at the last meeting, I think—it was put in at the Mansion House—I have given it to the Treasury (Produced), signed by Pappadaki, December 7th, 1894—I do not remember that I knew the date for which the meeting was called, at the time—a question arose with regard to the preliminary expenses to start with, and we agreed that it would not be right to debit the whole of the preliminary expenses in the one account, that that would be spread over a term, and therefore in this account I think we debit them with a third of the preliminary expenses; we deal with it in our report—the word "bonuses" used by us on both occasions represents either securities or shares; something other than cash that had been received, and some-thing, therefore, that would have to be realised before its proper amount could be ascertained; that was not our object in using the words in our report, "subject to realisation"—we did not know they were worth £48,200, or anything like that; we put in "bonuses valued by the directors, but which are subject to realisation," so that any one might see it was an uncertain figure—we did that for our own protection, and the protection of the shareholders—at the end of our balance-sheet we say, "We have examined the foregoing balance-sheet and profit and loss account, and find them to be in accordance with the books of the corporation in London, and, subject to our report of this date, we believe them to be a correct statement of the corporation's affairs"; so it would be perfectly clear to everyone who got this balance-sheet that there was a report, of this date of ours, and that the certificate was made subject to it—I forget whether this shareholder of whom I have spoken was Mr. Hedger—I could not say he was not, but it was some share
holder, or someone purporting to be a shareholder, on behalf of whom Messrs. Lewis and Lewis asked us to supply a copy of our balance-sheet and report, and we supplied them with both—one would be useless with
out the other, I should imagine—that was after the balance-sheet and

report were issued to the meeting—I cannot remember the date; it would be after the meeting, from what I remeiuher—the object in sending them afterwards was that someone wanted them—the letters will show; I forget what date it was—I do not remember hearing that there was an action pending against the Financial Times by the bank, and that Messrs. Lewis and Lewis were acting as solicitors for the Financial Times in a libel action in respect of the affairs of this bank—I might have heard rumours about it, possibly; if so, it has entirely gone from my memory now—I represent that the directors saw these accounts in the form in which they are drawn up now before December 7th; that is to say, document 224; that is our balance-sheet, with the certificate appended—I do not represent that the directors ever saw that before December 7th, as they were drawn up there at the finish on December 7th—they were corrected right up to date—we were working at it right up to November 30th, when I attended at the bank with the completed accounts, etc., and then I asked for a cheque—the accounts were then in the com
pleted form as they were eventually produced on December 7th—I attended with them all ready, but wanted cash or a cheque before I would hand them over—I did not hand them over till December 7th—I do not say they had not seen the figures, because we had had interviews right up to that date with the directors and the secretary right along, but they did not get these identical accounts, I mean; they had not got these actual signed documents, but they had seen the figures—by November 30th they had seen the figures, with the exception of trifling alterations—what I mean is, the accounts were not new to them; they knew the main features of them, no doubt—all the things Mr. Baker specially refers to in his letter are things that are in our report, and not in the balance-sheet—they had not seen the report; they had seen the accounts—they had seen the draft of this profit and loss account and balance-sheet, or very similar ones, practically identical, I think—they had not seen the report he means.

Cross-examined by MR. GRAIN. I think I saw Singleton twice, and my clerks saw him—I asked for the secretary, and saw Singleton, who referred me to F. J. Baker—beyond that, I do not remember having any communication with him during the whole time I was preparing the report—I do not believe I asked for F. J. Baker; I asked to see Mr. A. F. Eaker I think, about the items in the promotion account—I did not have much conversation with him; it was more my clerks than myself—it would be about that item of £4,777—I think I inquired from him about the minute, or one of the minutes, of April 18th, 1893—a portion of the minute is: "The founders' account having been submitted to Mr. Stokes and Mr. Lambert, these gentlemen reported that they had been through the same, and were satisfied with the amounts, and that the same was in order, showing that the sum of £6,907 had been paid by the founders, thus leaving a balance now due to them of £4,777; I believe that is what I inquired about from Singleton; it was a very long time back—I had had this minute before me, and I had read it, and I considered it as audited—I understood him to be the pro
moter, and then I believe I wanted information from him as to that portion of the minute of April 18th, 1893—he gave me no informa
tion; what we were asking for were the items of that account—beyond

that, I do not think I have had any communication with him at all—all the communication I have had with any person of the name of Baker was with the person who has been called on the part of the Crown.

Cross-examined by MR. HALL. I know Mr. Lambert by sight—I saw him, I think, about half-a-dozen times during the four months—I believe I had an interview with him with reference to the valuation of these securities—I cannot say that he objected to the words, "as valued by the directors," saying that it was not his valuation at all—I won't say that he did not—the difference, from a shareholder's point of view, be
tween bonuses subject to realisation and bonuses valued by the directors, but which are subject to realisation, is that the directors are responsible for the value—I cannot say whether Mr. Lambert refused to be respon
sible for any such valuation; I have no recollection of his ever having said such a thing to me—the date at which this report was actually delivered was December 7th—I suppose the directors would rely on my requiring the vouchers, and seeing that they were in order—the vouchers are not in the hands of the directors, but in the hands of their servants, and important documents I should expect to find in the manager's hands—I did not prepare this list of the assets of the bank—it is our clerk's hand
writing—I believe, as a matter of fact, it came from Beall really—I do not believe that Mr. Lambert told me anything as to the assets of the bank; he was asked, like the others, to produce the vouchers—he knew they were not forthcoming, and it was not for us to find them—the people who had the custody of them would have to produce them and satisfy me as an auditor—in 1894, when we prepared this report, I suppose we were satisfied as to these securities being the property of the corporation—I really forget now; we put the matter exactly in our report as to what we thought then—it is true, as stated by Mr. Wain in that letter, that I declined to part with the report until I had a cheque, and the directors were pressing me pretty strenuously to get the report.

Cross-examined by MR. A. GILL. If it be the fact that Mr. Lambert did not value these shares at £48,000, I suppose it would follow that the statement in the balance-sheet as we sent it out, that they were valued by the directors at that amount, was not true—that sum of £48,000 was not exactly meant to represent their face value—it is a little different; that was the value arrived at by the two directors—we were requested to put them in at that value—I cannot remember who requested me to do it, but it was by the directors, or we should not have put it in our report, and I take it to have very likely been done at a meeting of the board; from what I remember the values were put on them by Mr. Beall, and they were supported by the directors; they were corroborated by the directors—I think he supplied them with the information—those words in the drafts, "As valued by the directors," were put in the final settlement of the draft; they were discussed with the directors—whether they agreed with them, they knew of my intention at the time—I am prepared to swear that they knew those words would go in; I would not take it in any other way—I had discussed them with Mr. Wain many, many times before that—there was an opportunity of discussing the final draft; he could have discussed it after he got it, on December 7th—he could have done it; I do not say there was any discussion after the 7th;

there was nothing to prevent his discussing it—I do not know what date the meeting was—I did not know that it had to go to the printers that very night, I have forgotten—if my report were read to the meeting, and also the description in the accounts not altered, that would, I believe, clearly show what my position in the matter was with regard to the valuation—very likely I got information that the securities I wished to see were in the possession of Mr. Beall—the next letter is dated August 27th, and is addressed to Mr. Wain: "We have now got the papers connected with your audit so far as we can near completion, but we shall be glad to have your decision as to the writing up of the books, more especially the cash-book"—Mr. Wain may have gone away on his holiday on the next day or two after receiving the letter from me of August 27th—he may have been away the greater part of September—this letter says that he was going away the next Friday—letter 245, of December 1st, says: "I have never expressed any opinion that you were interested in the promotion."

By MB. ISAACS. At the Police-court I said: "When that report was sent in the directors asked me to bring in the bonus mentioned at an amount of £48,200. Wain and Lambert asked me to do this"—I was asked how the figures were arrived at, and, from what I recollect, Mr. Beall supplied the figures, and the directors fathered them—I said that I got it from the directors, but Mr. Beall supplied them with the figures—Wain and Lambert asked me to bring in the bonuses to the amount of £48,200, and that £48,200 was supplied, I believe, by Beall; he was there to discuss it—the bonus shares were found out, I think, in the ordinary way—we in
quired, as our letters show, from the directors; we got a list, I believe, from Beall and Co.—I am clear as to the list coming from Beall and Co.—they were supposed to hold them; the secretary, F. J. Baker, said they held them—we saw what they could show us, and formed our own opinion about them; how we should deal with them—we saw the direc
tors on them—the directors were only Wain and Lambert, and we saw sometimes one, sometimes the other, and sometimes both; but mostly, I think, as the correspondence shows, Mr. Wain, and, of course, frequently we saw Mr. Beall, who was the financial manager—while Mr. Wain was away we saw Lambert; we saw them occasionally, all three—I cannot re
member which first asked me to bring the bonus Shares into account as profits—I know it was at the request of all—from what I recollect, the figures were supplied by Mr. Beall, the financial manager; he put the figures on them, and the directors took his figures in the usual way.
By MR. HALL. At the Police-court I was examined by Mr. Bodkin—I was not cross-examined, the Magistrate having intimated that he was going to commit the case for trial.

Re-examined. I think that is the very list of these securities which Mr. Beall supplied me with (Produced)—Exhibit 241 is in answer to my letter complaining of the omission of the words "valued by the directors," and this is the answer which I received from Mr. Wain: "Dear Sir,—I read your report to the meeting, and fully explained that the valuation was the directors' and not yours"—I saw in the minute that the item £6,907, the expenses in connection with the

formation of the company, bad been referred to Messrs. Stokes and Lambert as a committee to consider it—they had certified it as right—I do not think Mr. Lambert ever gave me any informa
tion as to what materials he had before him when he certified that as correct—we asked for the items of the account many times, and could notget them—I do not remember that Lambert ever told me on what materials he had certified that as being the correct amount—on some occasions I saw Singleton when I was engaged on this work at the office of the bank—I remember his coming down into the downstairs office on one occasion when I had got some questions on with the clerk, who was at work, as to the promotion account—he was down on that business, I understood, but whether I put the questions to him myself, or whether my clerk did, I cannot remember now—I have got before me in my book of the bank the establishment account which appears as Exhibit 222 in the Book of Exhibits—I cannot positively say whether that was prepared by my clerks or by the bank—it was prepared after I came, I should say—some of the items might have been commenced—I cannot say—the item is "By T. Birtwistle, 40 £5 shares, £200; "there is no date to it—I did not make it by my own hand—I cannot remember if the entry was in the account before I came—my journal was made at the time of the audit—this entry about Birtwistle's shares was made by my clerk, under my direction—it is a journal entry that has come under my notice, or it would not be here—I do not recollect how that list came; it came with the papers we had; I imagine when we took the other papers from the bank; it came from Beall's office, I believe—I do not know the writing—I do not recognise it as any of my clerks".

MR. WALKER, I am a clerk in the Patent Office, and produce the file relating to certain patents—726, dated February 9th,! 883, to Mr. F. Livet, is for an improvement in furnace bars, and in clinker slicing tools to be used therewith—that patent expired on February 9th. 1896, through non-payment of the fees, £14; in the ordinary course it had got one year to run; fourteen years is the time—if £ 14 had been paid it would have continued—then 4,872, of July 22nd, 1890, is for an improved steam gsnerator; that is to Livet, too; that expired on July 22nd, 1894, through non-payment of the fees then due—1,092, of June 13th, 1891, for cremating town dust and like refuse on a new sanitary principle, was also granted to Livet; that expired on June 13th, 1897—the cause of the lapse of that one was through non-payment of the fees of £7, the sixth year of the renewal fee—then 20,236, December 11th, 1890, an improved setting for Lancashire steam boilers, is one of Livet's patents—that expired on December 11th, 1895—there is no entry of an assignment of those patents to the British Refuse or the London Refuse Company.
Cross-examined by MR. A. E. GILL. With regard to the second patent there is no mention made of Parliamentary proceedings to revive it that would not be entered.
Thursday, November 9th, 1899.

EGERTON SPENCER GREY . I am an Official Receiver in bankruptcy—I had the conduct of Mr. Beall's first bankruptcy in 1893—I am the Official Receiver in his present bankruptcy—his petition was filed on March 23rd of the present year—immediately on learning that I sent to

Mr. Beall's office and took possession of a number of his papers—they were brought to my department, and I have been through them since that time—I had in my possession for some time, from the Solicitor to the Treasury, the books and documents of the London and Scottish Bank—I have been through the books, and examined them closely—I agree with Mr. Abbott that they are not properly kept—the cash-book kept by Colee is not a proper cash-book at all; it is not a proper cashier's book—it does not give you sufficient information—it starts after the first moneys dealt with by Singleton—that was not Mr. Colee's fault; it does not start with that balance that should havo been in hand; and as to the keeping of the book, it is impossible to ascertain from merely looking at the book which are receipts and which are payments, because they are dealt with in precisely the same way—for instance, if the cashier receives £100 from Mr. Jones, he puts on the debit side of the account "Mr. Jones £100," and on the oilier hide of the account there also appears "Mr. Jones £100 '—if he pays Mr. Jones £100, he draws a cheque to Mr. Jones, and on the debit side appears "Mr. Jones £100," and on the credit side "Mr. Jones £100," and therefore, without tracing it through the bank pass-book or by some other means, it is impossible at a glance to see whether it is a receipt or a payment I do not suggest that it is an intentional concealment, but from the system it is impossible to trace it—I am able to get at what was done with the pass-book, and so on—the cash-book is not a record of cash received by the company, but only of cash received bv the cashier: there are omissions from that cash-book of money paid by the public for shares—I have noticed from time to time in that cash-book a I the initials of the directors, including those of Mr. Wain and Mr. Lambert, and also in the petty cash-book; the first petty cash-book being missing, in the second I find similar initials—I think in cash-book No. 4, folio 85, there is the establishment expenses account—I do not find among the bank's papers or any of the bank I ooks any parti
culars of or vouchers for the sum of £6,909; the only reference I can find is the minute of April 18th—I have read Mr. Abbott's report, and notice in it he states that a sum of £1,642 10s. was not handed over by Mr. A. F. Baker to the London and Scottish Bank—I cannot say if that is a cor
rect figure—I have not checked it; I have no means of checking it, because, in the absence of the shareholders' ledger, I cannot say what was received by the promoters prior to going to allotment—Mr. Abbott said there was a shareholders' ledger, but I have not been able to verify his account—I find in the establishment expenses account a deduction from the £6,909 of £2,132—I have not been able to find in the books of the bank, or among its papers, any particulars of or vouchers for any items going to make up that sum of £1,232; there is no record of any date anterior to the company going to allotment—I find in the establishment expenses account an entry of the amount paid by A. F. Baker on account of the establishment expenses previous to account being taken over by the board, £1,855; I cannot give you any information as to how that figure was made up—I cannot tell how that contra entry, "Payments made to A. F. Baker, as per bank passbook, £1,855," comes to be entered there; I suppose the explanation of that is that A. F. Baker had received pay
ments amounting to £1,855 prior to these books being started, because

the date is March, 1893—I cannot verify that item from the com
pany's bank pass-book—in the establishment expenses Beall's accounts, Nos. 1 and 2, are ordinary drawing accounts—there was no item of esta
blishment expenses through that account, that I am aware of—in the books of the bank, in the cash-book, I find also an account of the Atlas Contracting Syndicate, opened on February 7th, 1894, and continued until November 30th, 1894, and kept in that part of the cash-book which was apportioned to customers' account; and, so far as the book is con
cerned, that appears to be a customers' current account—from my exami
nation of the London and Scottish Bank cheques, I do not find that the cheques which are drawn according to the books on the Atlas Contracting Syndicate account were really drawn by the directors of the London and Scottish Bank in every case; the large cheques were, including Nos. 219, 220, and 221, in the exhibits, which were in payment of the Atlas promotion expenses; and in addition to those three, there are a number of others of larger amounts—I also found a directors' attendance-book; and, looking at that, I find that Wain attended 69 meetings and Lambert 71—loose in one of the books of the bank I found what purports to be a re
solution signed by all four directors, Wain, Greville, Stokes and Lambert—it shows first of all a list of 151 shares applied for, then it recites that 2,485 shares had been previously allotted—I do not know if 2,485 was the number of shares previously allotted by the signatories—there is a register, which gives the date of entry as a member—I find from the books of the company that Lambert held no sharps at all—there was no qualification—Lambert held no shares at any time in the company accord
ing to the register; I can find no trace of any—Wain is entered on the register under the date of July 17th, 1893—the first payment made in re
spect of shares was August 25th, 1893, £10 according to the books—he is entered on the register for 20 shares, and in the cash book, on folio 60, the entry is: "To cheque, J. W. C. Wain, for shares, £10"—I find on December 7th, 1894, that Wain's account is credited with the sum of £170 13s. 4d.—other entries in the books show that that was a credit for directors' foes, and the book shows that £100 of the £170 13s. 4d. was credited to his share account—the £10 paid on August 25th, 1893, and the £100 apparently credited to his share account in December, 1893, is the total amount that I can find that Wain ever paid for the shares, and I see a pencil note in the share register as showing that those are the amounts paid by him; I do not know who made the pencil note; it was made before the register came into my possession—there is no record of founders' shares in the books, or of the number of founders' shares actually issued—no counterfoil book has come into my possession—it would not be possible without a record of how many founders' shares were issued to properly declare a dividend or distribute a dividend—the ordinary shareholders would get the preference—I find an account opened headed "W. J. Carruthers Wain," promotion account, in the book pre
pared by Messrs. Abbott for the purpose of the audit—I find that that book credits Wain, as due to him from the bank, with £469 5s.—March, 1893, is the date—August 16th, 1893, "To cash, £100,': is the first entry of payment of any part of that sum—J remember in Mr. Abbott's account that he sets out as due to Mr. Wain the sum of £313 13s., on the promo
tion

account—in. Mr. Wain's account I find five items, which I have marked, coming together to £165 12s.—deducting the £165 12s. from the £469 5s„ I get a sum of £303 13s.—I do not find that amount of £303 138. in any other account—the amounts are dated August 18th, August 18th, September 7th; then there are two without dates, which may belong to the preceding entry of September 7th—he had on August 16th and August 15th about £100 on account of the whole—I find this sum of £303 13s. was paid to Mr. Wain by cheques of the bank, with the exception of £ 10 3 13s., which was credited to his current account, so in that way £469 5s. was discharged—that sum of £469 5s. and these payments have nothing to do with the sum of 330 paid by the Bank re Paris office on April 4th, 1893; that is a separate cheque—in the minute-book of the company I find that a dividend was declared of 7 per cent, in October, 1893, up to September 13th, 1893—I have been through the books of the bank, for the purpose of arriving at the bank's financial position on Sep
tember 13th, 1893—the account which I have prepared is Exhibit 302—I find that the expen
e of working the business up to September 13th, 1893, was £2,508 11s. 10d.—those working expenses are from March 13th, in
cluding items, directors' fees, £536; general salaries, £478; financial manager, £225; then law charges, £463, rent, and sundry expenses—I find, on the credit side, that the bank earned £837 10s. 8d., so that it cost the bank £2,508 11s. to earn £837 10s. 8d., leaving a deficiency to the bank of £1,671 1s., 2d. on the working expenses—supposing a bill for £100 was discounted at 10 per cent, I credit them with £10 interest earned, but if that bill subsequently is dishonoured there is an actual loss on the transaction of £90—among the £837 10s. 8d. I have included an item of £60 as interest earned in regard to a loan to Colonel Schaffer—Colonel Schaffer's bill was eventually dishonoured, and the loss
on Schaffer was £357, because the bank held certain securities—the minute appears here—the £837 10s. 8d. is the outside they could have earned for interest, if everything had been paid—I do not wish to be understood as saying that they ought to have known on September 13th that the loss would be made—I have also in this account, at page 316, referred to the expenses relating to the Paris branch, the prospectuses and agency charges of the promotion, which comes to £11,790; and then there are two small items added, which with those would amount to £1,671, and altogether they show a loss up to September 13th of £13,471 2s. 6d.—I have made no allowance for bad debts in the account; it is without making allowance for bad debts and charging the whole of the promotion expenses up to that time—on September 13th, 1893, in our judgment, and according to my account, there was no justification for declaring any dividend at all—in Messrs. Abbott's account, Exhibit 224,1 find an item of £425 investments—I find that Colonel Schaffer was a borrower from the bank upon a bill—the total amount of the advance to him was £782, but there is interest de
ducted, £120—the date of the original transaction was March 30th, 1893—it is the first transaction of the bank—Colonel Schaffer deposited as a security for that loan 200 £5 District Messenger shares, and also 1,000 Union Newspaper shares—I find that the bank took over those shares, the "District Messenger" and the Union Newspaper, at £425—Colonel Schaffer never repaid the amounts which he borrowed; so that the bank

would appropriate the security which he deposited—that £425 was a collateral security against an undischarged debt—I have been through the list of bonus shares—leaving the London Refuse Company and the British Refuse Company for the moment, I find on the list the Grappler Tyre shares, £300—that was received in regard to a loan to Mr. Cottam—it is entered in this list of bonus shares as of the value of £300, as if it was received by the bank from Mr. Cottam—I find, too, 100 Horton Ice anl five Globe Debenture shares, by looking at the minutes of the company; I find that they were deposited as against a loan to Mr. J. Hunter Steven-son—they were deposited as security for a promissory note on June 21st,. 1893—I find also a list of bonus shares, 20 Elmore Copper Company and 45 Buenos Ayres Tramway Company—they were deposited as against an advance to a Mr. Clarke to secure a bill dated May 24th, 1893, at three months, renewed August 26th at a charge of £10—the loan was repaid—it was finally met on December 10th, 1894, after several renewals—on payment of the bill the security was returned to Mr. Clarke—the bill was finally met on December 10th, 1894—then I also find a further 100 Buenos Ayres Tramway Company shares, deposited as security against a loan to Mr. Reeves on Mr. Reves' promissory note for three months—that loan was not repaid—it was subse
quently collected, I think, by the liquidator—I find among the Buenos Ayres shares 105 Olympic Music Hall shares deposited as against a loan to Mr. Shenton—the minute is: "It was reported that an advance of £90 had been made to Mr. Shenton at the request of Mr. Greville on his acceptance of two months date for £100, the security he lodged being 100 ordinary shares of £1 each in the Olympic Music Hall and five founders' shares of £20 each"—I find a further minute at page 118: "he George Shenton's loan," on October 3rd, when all four directors were present: "The secretary reported that this gentleman had been adjudi
cated bankrupt. It was also stated that a petition had been presented to wind up the Olympic Music Hall, Limited, and that on inquiries being made as to the value of the shares, no offer could be got for them. The solicitors were instructed to appear in both cases"—on page 124 of the minutes there is a reference to it: "The secretary produced a copy of the petition to wind up the Olympic Music Hall"—I find at page 161 of the minutes: "Re George Shenton's loan: The secretary reported that this gentleman had been adjudicated bankrupt, and the first meeting of his creditors was to be held on the 24th inst.; proof of our debt had been lodged"—the last in the bonus list is an acceptance of a Mr. Wallace for £300, and, looking at the minute of May 24th, 1894, I see they say they will not discount the bill because the inquiries are unsatis
factory, and, further on, they say that Mr. Wallace's acceptance is no use, and afterwards they returned the draft on September 9th—it was eventually discounted because they got judgment on the bill—that acceptance of £300 was not met at all; Mr. Wallace became bankrupt—I was not his Official Receiver, it came through the department—I find that John Sheridan, by the loan ledger, folio 20, borrowed a sum of £600 from the bank upon a bi 1 of exchange—this agreement, dated July 17th, 1893, was found amongst Mr. Beall's papers, signed by John Sheridan; it is directed to the directors of the London and Scottish Banking and

Discount Corporation, Limited—(Agreeing, as promoter of Wulffs Circus, Limited, to provide and pay £775 advanced to him by them, whether these companies go to allotment or not, on condition of their dis
counting another bill for £125)—so on July 17th there was a further advance of £125; it is referred to in the agreement—in the minute of May 25th, 1893, at page 47, I find that there were present Mr. Stokes, Mr. Lambert, Mr. Greville, and Mr. Wain, and Mr. Brandon, solicitor: "In the matter of Manole Hold and Swindley's Patent Tyres it was reported that since the last board meeting the committee had approved of an advance of £500 for three months upon the terms and conditions in the agreement, and on the understanding that the principal should be guaranteed, and it was agreed that half the profits to be derived from the transaction be paid to the guarantor"—so that in the inception of the John Sheridan transaction it would appear that a charge over the Manole Hold and Swindley's Patent Tyres and the Wulffs Circus shares was given—I recollect the minutes showing that Wulffs Circus, Limited, never went to allotment, nor the Manole Hold Tyre either—I see that the letter of September 15th, 1893, copied in the letter-book, says "Wullf's Circus apparently exists only in imagination"—that letter was written to Sheridan—among Beall's papers I find letter 321, from John Sheridan to Messrs. pany—then they altogether parted with £4,225, or thereabouts—I have had before me the banking account of J. B. Morrison (Exhibit 182)with the Metropolitan and Birmingham Bank, and also some cheques of Mr. Haley-the first cheque is No. 27, for £100, dated November 1st, 1892,

Best, W. Collins, and Herbert Cummings: £646 15s. altogether—11 of those 20 customers were afterwards made bankrupt, and they have been since through the Court, taking Beall and Co as two—Octavius Stokes was at Green wich, and I have no personal knowledge of that—Meeking was bankrupt; that was another High Court; that was the Printing Press Agency—they were most of them overdrawn; some of them were not—the chief portion of the business which the bank did was discounting

bills and lending money—in the list I made up to September 13th there is a list of debtors to the bank of persons who have borrowed from the bank—on page 319 I find that the total amount lent, which amounted to £473, including overdrafts on current accounts, was £6,768, 14 s. 8d., and that the bank recovered from those persons £4,284, but lost as bad debts £2,474 13s. 7d. up to September 13th—20 per cent, and over was charged on acceptances—the bill-book will show the renewals; the bills were mostly renewed when they matured—this is the bill-book (Produced)—the discount business, taken from the point of view of profit to be earned, was a very insignificant one for the whole period—there was very little money to lend, and therefore the amount was obviously small—during the first six months the interest earned was £837 10s. 8d., and the total loss on those transactions was £2,436 11s. 11., 11d.—in my balance-sheet, at page 315, I set out £514 as being; cash at the bankers—a number of cheques were outstanding, amounting to £282 16s. 9d., leaving available cash at the bankers £231 11s. 9d.—I said £17 13s. 8d. was the cash in the hands of the cashier—how I cannot say, but I made a mistake in that item—it should, in fact, be £341 11s. 2d.; therefore cash in hand at the bank is £573 2s. 11d. instead of £249—there is an error, therefore, of £320 odd in the total, but at the foot of the account there is an item of balance unaccounted for; it will be reduced by that amount—it will not affect in any way the profit and loss account—I cannot tell you whether there was any reason for the cashier having such a large sum in hand at that time—there was no loan made the next day or shortly after that might account for it—I do not think that the cashier had an unusual sum at this time; it was to meet cheques and current expenses—it got less as time went on, until it was replenished by cashier's cheques for current expenses.

Cross-examined by MR. ISAACS. There are altogether right through the bank 34 current accounts; ordinary and current; accounts—some of those happened in one transaction, but they are opened as current accounts—there is only one transaction in one or two of these—up to September 13th there were 20 accounts opened—the 34 relate to over the whole period—10 were overdrawn to the extent of £473; that was the total overdraft, of which £346 9s. 8d. represented Beall's Account No. 1, a small amount represented Beall's account No. 2, and the balance was the Printing Press Agency (Meeking) £25 17s. 1d., Hunter Stevenson £2 2s. 1d., W. J. Carruthers Wain £2 7s. 8d., Fordyce Sheridan on his current account 2s. 1d., Miss McGregor £10 17s. 10d., Octavius Stokes £50 2s. 10d., Pappadaki£18 4s. 7d., and S. Bramall £15 10s. 10d.—Pap
padaki repaid the whole of the amount eventually by 10s. a week, I think—the bank lost nothing by that—I think they were justified in looking upon it as a good advance—five of those 10 customers were indebted on their loans; the object being to show that several of those customers that were apparently in credit on their current accounts were debtors to the bank on loan accounts—there was nothing due at that time by Best; there was a discounting acceptance drawn on T. Jarvis—Best is the drawer—it was a bill for £50 due on September 30th—it was renewed and eventu
ally paid on November 6th of the following year—up to September 13th there was nothing due—with regard to Mrs. Sala, I find one bill for £355,

due August 15th, paid on August 16th, and another dated August 18th, due on October 21st—Collins' was a two months acceptance dated June 17th, due August 20th, and it was renewed monthly until it was eventu
ally dishonoured, and it has not since been paid—Collins then gave some shares in the International Electric Lighting Company—the bill of Mrs. Sala is for £100 due on October 17th, then renewed and eventually paid on February 28th, 1894—another bill was given, but eventually it was met—these amounts were discount liabilities, but the time for payment had not actually matured; the proceeds of the bills were credited to the current accounts, and thus created the credit balance on current accounts—when I went in as an Official Receiver, I took possession of all the papers of every description—it appears from the share register that with respect to each person's allotment there is the date at which he became a member, which would mean the date at which the allotment was made to him, I should say—Mr. Abbott, no doubt, had the books in his possession, from which he prepared the accounts down to March, 1894, and those books passed into the possession of the liquidator and into my possession subse
quently—from those books, taking them to be correct, there is no diffi
culty in getting at the facts—I have as far as possible checked the figures with the cashier's books—Mr. Abbott's account does not relate to the period beginning September 13th; he deals with a different period—I had to use the same materials that he had to a very great extent; for instance, to show the commissions earned, I took the details of the commissions earned up to March 31st, according to Mr. Abbott's statement, and then I went through the same books for the subsequent period, and then I went through the cashiers books to see if those amounts had been received or earned—the documents that I received on behalf of Beall when I took possession as Official Receiver were very, very numerous—there were some books, but very few entries in them—I looked through every one before I went to the Mansion House—I extracted from the papers about one hundredweight that appeared to have a bearing on the case, and the agreement with the Sberidans was one of those that was not put in; I cannot tell you why, except that there were a great many left out—there were 400 exhibits put in—I think I had the prospectus of the London Refuse Company; that is the document that was put in with the illustra
tions—there were a large number of loose documents—the founders' shares were share warranto to bearer, and if 2,000 founders' sharps were payable to the promoters, so far as the company was concerned, they would only have to deal with the 2,000 founders' shares, they could not deal with any more—as they were share warrants to bearer, it was quite immaterial to the company how they were distributed—it is very unusual to advertise the dividends, and to let the holders of the warrants come forward and claim them, because in every other case that has come under my notice there has been a register showing the names of the original founders, and then it is invariably found, before the dividend is paid, how the founders' shares have been dealt with—my registration will not assist me to find out to whom the dividend is payable; it does not matter to whom it is payable, except at the time you pay the dividend—I debited all the preliminary expenses of them—I take them into the profit and loss account—of course the statement of affairs sets out all the

liabilities—it is right in making out your profit and loss account lo take into account the preliminary expenses—if there ia any future benefit to be derived from the preliminary expenses, then I think it would be just to spread them over the period during which the benefit will accrue, but where the whole expenditure has been made and there is no future benefit that can accrue, then the only way is to charge the whole to that period—take a case where large sums are spent on advertisements: it is very usual to extend the amount over an ascertained period, because it is thought that benefit will hereafter arise from those advertisements—that is frequently done—with regard to this particular case, I took my mind to September, 1893, in preparing this account; the profit and loss account is a very different thing to the capital amount, and whether or not a dividend may be declared without bringing into the profit and loss account, a loss on capital account, depends on circumstances; each case must be governed by the particular facts; and by the opinion I formed with the knowledge of the business as to whether the amount should be spread over, and as to the future benefit from the preliminary expenses that have been incurred in some cases, there can be no dispute—I took the whole amount of the stationery into account, but as it was impossible to ascertain the amount of stationery in hand on September 13th, I thought that would be a fair set off against the rebate on current bills, which I did not take into account—I made up the amount for the purposes of this case this year, 1899—having no means of finding out how much was left in stock on September 13th, 1893, I debited the whole amount—I recollect that Mr. Brandon had to go to Paris, and was there for more than a month, and eventually took possession of the office, and also that two of the directors had to go over; but that does not show me that the greater part of these expenses, "law charges £463 10s.," related to the Paris house litigation—I cannot speak as to details—of course, the bill would not come in for some time afterwards—I know ihere was a great deal of litigation—I brought into account the whole amount of the promotion account—on September 13th, 1893, there was a business going on—I do not think that part of these promotion expenses would be naturally to form that business—I think myself the whole amount should have been debited—there was no Paris house at that date; therefore, no future benefit could have accrued to the company in that respect—I have an item: "Liabilities, subscription received to September 30th, on ordinary shares, £16,188"—£200 of that relates to Blakiston's payments—I have treated that as a debit—it is not included in the £16,188—I should like to say as to that item that the balance unaccounted for is probably the difference between the amount I have taken and the actual account—it is impossible, in the absence of the shareholders' ledger, to ascertain the actual amount—I do not suggest that the unaccounted for balance was misappropriated—the balance unaccounted for would probably arise from there being some further pay
ments for shares which I have not found in the books—I said, "The balance unaccounted for is likely to have arisen from receipts from the shareholders which, in the absence of the shareholders' ledger, I have failed to trace"—I think that is probably the explanation of it—out of the whole amount of these cheques that have been paid, there is only one

that is traced into the Morrison account, and that is the £100 Haley cheque—there is something to be added, I do not know what the amount is, for costs of litigation—the company got a judgment on the Wallace bill, and then took bankruptcy proceedings; so that whatever the amount was that was expended on those costs would have to be added to the £4,000 odd that had been actually paid by the bank; they got nothing from the Sheridans at that time—the litigation was to enforce payment of the Morrison bill, not to recover the shares—I am not prepared to say that there was no litigation with regard to these shares—the settlement that was made was made in the bankruptcy proceedings; there was a petition filed by the bank against Sheridan; then that petition was dismissed—the particu
lars of the bonuses are in the ledger (Produced)—" 30,000 shares, £1 fully paid, in the London Steam Generator Company," are carried out at £30,000: 16,500 shares, £1 fully-paid, in the British Steam Generator, are carried out at £16,500—Wallace's acceptance for £300 is carried out at £300—if it is face value it would uot be carried out in the same way—we had no bonuses in the profit and loss account on September 13th—all I have taken in the account as credited was not in cash; it was earned, but it was not received, as a matter of fact—they had it in hand, because they only parted with the amount less interest; subject to the bills being met, it was earned—I was present at the Police-court right through—I heard Mr. Bowler called—the Alderman said he did not believe him.

Cross-examined by MR. HALL. I find no trace of suggestion against Lambert of having had any share in the promotion of this company at all—I do not think that he has had any money out of this company except what he has received by way of directors' fees—I think the account shows that at the date of the liquidation he was a creditor on a balance for £19 due to him—the account shows £69; that is made up by crediting him with a loan of £50—anyhow, he was a creditor at that time, according to the books—I do not know if the £50 was lent by Mr. Lambert on Decern ber 5th, and that he had a receipt for it.

Cross-examined by MR. A. GILL. £469 5s., which is entered in the minutes as due to Mr. Wain, was reduced to £303 13s., by a contra account of £165 12s.—that £303 13s. was paid to Mr. Wain—I have not found any vouchers relating to the account—there would be £280 in the first place due from Wain on his shares—of that £280, £10 was paid some time after allotment—then, in December, 1894, £100 was debited to his account for directors' fees—it came out of what was due to him for directors' fees; that would leave £90 still due—if there had been any
thing due from Mr. Wain on account of his shares it would have been the duty of Mr. Aitcheson, as liquidator, to have taken proceedings to recover it—I have no knowledge thai he did not take proceedings against Mr. Wain for any arrears of calls—I looked into the book to see whether this £90 was paid—the first place, I suppose, that anyone would look at would be in the share register—the shareholders' ledger does not give the dates when the moneys were received—there are two payments of £10 and £90 entered—then at a later date, in December, 1894, there is a further £100—in Wain's ledger account, page 105, I see an item, "October 27th, 1893, London and Scottish Banking and Discount Corporation, Limited: Re

shares £90, and the cheque identified, £14,506"—I have now no doubt that Wain paid for his shares; I had overlooked that—the share register shows the amount paid in respect of their shares—it does not act as a shareholders' ledger, because it does not give the dates when the amounts were received.

ROBERT SEAGER (Detective Inspector, City). On Thursday, June 15th, I received a warrant for the arrest of Beall—I made inquiries from that time with a view to finding him, and on June 20th I was with another inspector, Davidson, at Chapel Street, Edgware Road, and I saw Beall there—he came towards us—I said to him, "You know us, Mr. Beall," and he said, "Yes"—I said, "I hold a warrant for your arrest for fraud; shall I read it to you here or at the station?"—he said, "At the station, if you do not mind"—he said, "I heard of it last night, and was on my way to the City, and thought I might have seen some of you at my oflice"—he was then taken to the station, and formally charged and made no further reply—on the same day in the afternoon I saw Lambert at the Detective Office, Old Jewry; he was brought there by Mr. Beyfus, his solicitor—Mr. Beyfus spoke to me, and I then said to Lambert that I was a police-officer, and held a warrant for his arrest; I read it to him—he said, "As soon as I heard it I went to my solicitors, and then we came on here at once"—he made no further reply—about half-past five o'n that same day I saw Wain at the Detective Offices in Old Jewry, in charge of Sergeant Willis—I told him that I was a police-officer, and had a warrant for his arrest, and read it to him—he said, "There must be some mistake about that first date, as I was not connected with the company till some time after that"—the warrant put the conspiracy at the date of March 1st, 1892—then he was taken to the station, and also formally charged, and made no further reply.

----WILLIS (Detective Sergeant). I went on June 20th to Wain's address at 39, Hogarth Road, Earl's Court, and inquired for him, and in consequence of what I was told I sent for his doctor—I saw Mr. Wain and told him the charge—he said, "This is, I suppose, the outcome of touching pitch and becoming defiled"—I conveyed him to the Old Jewry, and read the warrant to him.

Cross-examined by MR. ISAACS. During the course of these proceedings I went to Messrs. Brandon and Nicholson's office—I saw Mr. Meadows, a clerk in their employ—I said I wanted to speak to him in connection with the affairs of the London and Scottish Bank—he said something to the effect that he knew nothing at all about them; that it was his principal, Mr. Jocelyn Brandon, who knew all about that, and I then saw Mr. Jocelyn Brandon—Mr. Brandon is alive now, as far as I know.
Re-examined I do not remember that Meadows told me anything about Mr. Brandon; as to whether he had at that time been subpoenaed or not.

JAMES MURPHY (Inspector, City,) About 2 o'clock on June 20th I went to 20, Lausanne Road, Peckham, and there saw Singleton—I told him I was a police-officer, and had a warrant for his arrest—I read it—he made no reply; he was taken to Cloak Lane Police-station and charged, and made no reply there.

p.hi: Beally in his defence, on oath, Hated that he had been in business in the

div1.p:
City as a solicitor since 1874, and became acquainted with Singleton in 1880; that in 1892 Singleton suggested the formation of a Scottish Banking and Discount Company; that no names of persons appeared on the pros
pectus of the bank except of those from whom he had had consent in writing; he said that he did not know the writer of the articles on the London and Scottish Bank; that the promotion expenses of the bank were to be paid by the sale of the founders' shares, and there was no agreement with regard to what he was to get out of the business; that the signatories to the memorandum of association were simply nominees of the promoters; that everything that was done was confirmed by the directors; that he attributed the failure of the bank to the fact thai certain promises which the promoters had received from Paris and Scotland were never fulfilled, which was apparently due to the failure at that period of the Australian banks and the Panama scandals; that there was a loss of some £2,000 on the Paris branch; that he never made a shilling profit out of his connection with the bank; that it was absolutely untrue that he instructed F. J. Baker to pack the meeting of the shareholders at Edinburgh; that meeting he attended, and sat next to the chairman; that it was untrue that he took away any of the books of the bank, in order that they might not fall into the hands of Mr. Aitcheson, the liqnidator, the documents which he took away referred to other matters, and they were preserved. With regard to the Norris action, he was advised that in law he could not win in any event; that in respect of the agreement of March 10th, 1892, which he pre
pared between A. F. Baker and J. H. Hamilton, under which Baker was to be allotted 2,000 founders' shares in the company, for services rendered; that he did not know who Hamilton was; that the signatories to the memorandum of association were not mere dummies; that the effect of the agreement was not to place the whole of the founders' shares in the possession of Singleton and himself; that the articles in the "Financial Gazette"laudatory of the bank were not inspired by him, nor did he know the writer; that he had no control over the "Financial Gazette"; that the "influential group of financiers" referred to in (he prospectus of the bank was not composed of himself and Singleton; that the group comprised agents in Algiers, Vienna, Paris, and elsewhere; that some were connected with the Panama Syndicate; that the founders' shares were sold from March, 1892; that no account was kept of the sales, beyond the counterfoils of the share warrants, to show what money had been received in respect of founders' shares, which were £1 shares, which were issued at £10; that there was no intention to deceive the public in omitting from the circulars the amount of the founders' shares; it was not done for the purpose of getting them to pay a premium of £9 on each share; that it would have been the same had they been issued at £20; thai the public would have taken them up had they known what rights they would secure; that he and Singleton were responsible for the issue of the founders' shares, which they honestly thought at one time would touch £30; that he submitted to judgment in the Norris action on the advice of his Counsel; that the names of Lard Elibank and Lord Waterpark appeared as "trustees," but it was not intended to represent to the public that those noblemen were con
nected with the bank; that there was a suggestion that, after the first issue of shares, the bank should negotiate a loan on the uncalled capital of the

p.hi:
company, and it was in this connection that trustees were appointed, and both Lord Waterpark and Lord Elibank resigned; that beyond what appeared in the books he could not mention what were the assets or invest
ments of the hank which were to be securities for the issue of the 4 3/4 per cent. debenture stock. He read several items which appeared in the books, and mentioned shares in other companies as assets of the bank. He denied being responsible for the entries in the book. He was financial manager, but he did not assist the directors in making up the 7 per cent. dividends, and as to the £48,200, which was included in the balance-sheet, he did not know who suggested it. The accounts were audited by a Mr. Weller, the directors taking the shares with regard to the item at their "face" value.

Lambert, in his defence, stated on oath that he first started in business with his father as a hosier at Nottingham; that he became aferwards con nected unth Mr. Number, the cycle manufacturer, and was a partner in that business, into which he put £5,000; that he was introduced to Beall and Wain in 1893, but did not know Singleton; that he was asked to find a responsible person to become a trustee of the bank, and approached Lord Waterpark, whose letter he regarded as a consent to act, and handed Lord Waterpark's letter to Beall; that there was every reason to believe that the com
pany would prove a great success, as there were many persons anxious to borrow money; that he did not know anything about the allotment of the founders' shares; that he regularly attended the meetings of the bank, at which Beall was present as financial manager; that with regard to the resolutions that were passed he acted in good faith; that at the time of the winding
up he was a creditor of the bank to the extent of£69; that except as fees as a director, he had not received, either directly or indirectly, a single shilling from the bank, and that the 7 per cent, dividend was suggested by Beall; that the figure £48,200 was not intended to represent the actual value of the shares it referred to, and if he had any reason to doubt Beall's good faith he would certainly not have joined the bank; that beyond asking Beall, he did not take any steps to ascertain whether the statements contained in the prospectus were true, and that he had acted in good faith throughout the whole of his transactions with the bank; that the City of London destroyed its refuse by cremation, but did not make use of the power obtained in the process; and that if the Corporation used this patent they might light half the City for nothing.

div1.p: Wain, in his defence, stated that until the Magisterial investigation he did not know anything of Singleton, neither had he any knowledge of the "Financial Gazette,"of the signatories to the memorandum of association, or of tht issue of the founders' shares of the bank, or of Lloyd Morgan and Co,; that he did not receive a penny in connection with the promotion of the company; that the failure of the business in Scotland was due in part to the attacks made on the bank and its officials by certain newspapers; that the statements in the prospectus were correct; that he considered the patent acquired by the Refuse Company as a very valuable one; that all their energies were devoted to make it a success; that Beall, Lambert, Mr. Priestley, and himself found the money to keep the company alive; that he did not believe that F. J. Baker ever received any instructions to pack the meeting of shareholders in Edinburgh; and that there was not the slightest
truth in the allegations made against him, [Wain here fainted, and had to he assisted from the Court.]

GEORGE ROBERT WHEELER . I am surveyor to the Westminster Vestry, and have been so for 18 years—in 1891 I saw Mr. Livet with regard to this destr uctor—he was the patentee; I believe he saw me with a view of getting the vestry to adopt it, and in 1894 the vestry adopted it—we are now working it, and have been ever since 1894, with great success—we have gained the whole of the power for lighting our stables with electric light, and doing all the work necessary, cutting blocks, making mortar, cutting chaff, and lifting goods with this destructor, and we have never burnt an ounce of coal since it has been put up—the one we have used has been one made in accordance with the Livet Patent entirely—Livet supervised the first construction of it, but he died, and then one of his representatives saw it completed—the exact invention which Mr. Livet patented is on the formation of the flues under the boiler, so that the fumes and smoke are so consumed that there is no nuisance, and the power that is produced by the steam generator is sufficient to do all the work that I think is necessary—the specification was brought to me by Mr. Livet some years ago—I do not think I ever knew anything of the prospectus of the London company—I have seen no reports—there has been a saving of £60 a-year, but had they adopted this report, and carried out the building which I proposed, I believe it would have been from £1,000 to £1,200 a-year—it they had burnt all their refuse in this way it would have saved them that—we only consume four loads a day, and they really collect 40 to 50 loads a day—I use it now for generating electric light; not for the streets, only for the stables—I suggested that it should be used for the streets; I think we should then save £l,000 to £1,200 ayear—the vestry is a small one—there are between 45 and 50 vestries as large as ours in London.

Cross-examined by the SOLICITOR-GENERAL. This apparatus was put up in 1894—Mr. Livet died soon after it was commenced—I saw Mr. Livet in 1891 or 1892—he had written several letters to my vestry, and asked them to construct such a thing, but, of course, vestries are not very quick in moving, and it took two or three years before they would adopt any
thing of the kind—then they adopted it on a very small scale; they have considered this larger one, but at the present time they have not adopted it—my suggestion has not been adopted because the barging away of the dust was very much reduced in price; it went from 2s. 8d. a load to 11d. a load—it became cheaper to barge it away even than to destroy it by this process—it is only for a time, I think—I believe it is a better system to destroy it than to throw it into the river.

Re-examined. I have no doubt as to the value of this process—if you barge away the stuff and get rid of it, you get no benefit from it; if you burn it, you get enough power to light your place with electric light, and if you have a large enough place, you would get enough light to light the streets, and save £1,200 a year—other vestries have not got rivers running through them, and, therefore, it costs them 2s. 8d. to 3s. a load-our vestry adopted it while the patent was going; we did not pay anything by way of royalty; we simply paid them £600 for the construction of the furnace and boiler; that was what

we paid Mr. Livet or his widow, I do not know which; it was no royalty—if we had to pay any royalty, it would come out of the figures I men
tioned as the saving to the vestry—it was put up as a test instalment, and also to give us assurance that it was a destructor that was no nuisance to the inhabitants.

FRANK HENRY CHEESEWRIGHT . I am a member of the Institute of Civil Engineers, a Fellow of the Royal Geographical Society, and a Fellow of the Society of Arts—I have been in practice for 30 years—I was intro
duced to this matter of the British Refuse Destructor about April, 1892—I did not know Mr. Livet before that—I went into the matter, and saw his process—I looked at the specification of the patent—I have no doubt that his invention was then protected by a patent—I know of Mr. Aston's opinion—I knew that that patent protected that invention—the peculiar feature of the invention was that as the heat of the furnaces had more energy in them the flues were narrowed, and as the energy got less the flues became larger, and there was a velocity of air through the fire
bars that was greater than you could ever get except by means of a forced draught—I know all the destructors, and this is the only one where an artificial draught is not created; the flues alter in their size: they expand—they are not elastic—these are con
structed to contract or expand as the heat or energy is greater or less—they are larger at one end than at the other—no doubt that was an original idea of Mr. Livet's—I formed a very high opinion of it; at that time, I may tell you, an experiment was being tried at a boiler in King's Road, Chelsea; I went there, and I was struck with the novelty and the magnifi
cence of the results; they were burning trade offal, and using no other power to keep the steam going; I asked the Assistant Locomotive Superin
tendent of the Midland Railway, Mr. Wetherburn, to accompany me and see it, and he could hardly believe that such a draught was caused by natural means, and he sent an assistant to the place, and he stayed there for a week to try and find out what was the cause of this draught—Mr. Wetherburn put £500 in it with a view of exploiting this patent—the next thing was the installation at Westminster Vestry; that was on a larger scale—I was satisfied with that—it was a practical test on a very extended scale—I have practised in Mexico City, and the municipality there are arranging for it, and £20,000 has been subscribed to make an installation on this principle—I went to Westminster to see this installation, and a large number of pressmen and other people connected with vestries went to see it—the unanimous opinion, so far as 1 could judge, was highly favourable—another installation was fitted up at Ira and Ickringill's at Keighley, in Yorkshire—I saw that—that is twice the size—it is working, and has proved an entire success—the installation at Ira and Ickringill's was for burning coal dust and dirt that could not be burnt under any other cir
cumstances—I put a very considerable sum into this; from first to last about £3,000—all that time I was assuming that this was a patent of Mr. Livet's, and that the patent was running—I know Mr. Livet entered into arrangements with the British Refuse Company for the purpose of financing this patent—I went all over the country; I saw different vestries, different corporations, with a view of inducing them to put their money into the business; I also prepared and read papers on the subject

at different societies, and in that way the money went; I also lent money to Mr. Livet—I took some acceptances from Mr. Livet for some £2,000 or £3,000, all of which represented money lent—then came Mr. Livet's sudden death, and I had to take up those acceptances and repay them myself—the money was sent to my office to pay the fees, and my clerk, who was instructed to pay those fees, took the date of the payment of the fees from the date the patent was granted, not from the time when the patent was applied for: and a private Bill was promoted in Parliament for the purpose of getting the patent prolonged or renewed; it was refused on the ground that they could not take advantage of negligence, and so the patent lapsed—Mr. Glaskin was the engineer to the company, and I was consulting engineer.

Cross-examined by MR. A. GILL. This document (Produced)is a copy of a report made by me, dated January, 1895, to the directors of the London Kefuse Company; I find this: "The company has granted certain rights to the subsidiary company for London and the six home counties This company has been formed under the title of the London Refuse Steam Generator and Electric Power Cor
poration, Limited, with an issue of £300,000, of which this parent company receive 100,000 shares of £1 each for its rights"—that is right—"The London Refuse Steam Generator and Electric Power Corporation, Limited, are on the eve of obtaining many installations on the Livet principles, and mention must be made of the Vestries of Shore
ditch, St. Luke's, Croydon, St. George's, Strand, City Commissioners, and Chelsea. The reason of several of these works not being settled is through the vestrymen being elected. As for the prospectus of the company, I can certainly do nothing but express my belief upon my ultimate success, as there is absolutely no other system that produces the same results as the Livet system"—that was my belief, and it is so now—I represented that to the directors.

Cross-examined by the SOLICITOR-GENERAL. I am not active in advertis
ing the merits of this process beyond giving lectures and going to the vestries—I do not know that I have given you a lecture to-day—I was all over the country expounding the merits of the process—the way I made up the £3,000 was not only expenses, but endorsing the acceptances of Mr. Livet, which his sudden death made me responsible for—in addition to that, I incurred expenses travelling about the country—that makes up the £3,000—I had not much suc
cess in my tours—they listened to me, but they would not perform—I had a most favourable reception, but no one would take the pro cess; as Mr. Wheeler said, the vestries are very difficult to move; I suggest that as the natural history of vestrymen they are very conser
vative; they have not an old-fashioned prejudice in favour of doing things as cheaply as possible, because had they adopted Livet's system they would have adopted a system cheaper than they are doing now by carting and barging—as to Mr. Wheeler stating that barging turned out to be cheaper, and that accounted for its not being taken up, that gentleman must have made a small mistake, because anyone going up the City Road would see an installation, a tremendous one beside a canal, where they could have barged their

refuse away, but they do not, they burn it—that is St. Pancras; the City of London destroy their refuse by cremating it, and the St. Luke's Vestry do, but they make no use of it—I suppose the City of London is conser-servative—I do not think it is due to some other cause, because here is a fact that remains, that they are wasting heat every day by the destruction of the City refuse, and they are making no use of it, whereas if they erected the installation of Livet they would be lighting the City for nothing—I can-not say why they do not adopt this invaluable process; I can only repeat what I say, that the City of Mexico are going to adopt it—that is governed by a municipality, like the City of London; like our veatries—I do not know whether they are much more enlightened there, they will be, but at home in London, this process has met with very indifferent success.

Re-examined by MR. HALL. The cartage payments have nothing to do with the non-adoption of the process by the vestries; it may be that the contracts for carting or barging have not run out—that may interefere with it.

BEALL SINGLETON and WAIN—
GUILTY . BEALL—
Four Years' Penal Servitude.
SINGLETON—
Eighteen Months in the Second Class.
WAIN—
Twelve Months in the Second Class.
LAMBERT received a good character—
NOT GUILTY .
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, NOVEMBER 20TH, 1699.
